Diuretic to clear the urinary passags. clear the passages
Errkine - to promote sneezing
Emminagogun - to promote the minstrual(menstrual?) discharge
Antiscorbutic - Good against the scurvy
Diaphoritic - to promote perspiration
non conductors of electricity - glass - resin, wax, sulpher, silk, baked wood, dry woolen substances
Antiseptic - preserver from putrification
500 species of Quadrupeds
4000 do(ditto) Birds
2500 do(ditto) Fishes
700 do(ditto) Reptiles
44000 do(ditto) Insects
Europe has 14 volcanoes 
205 volcanoes known
107 in the Islands 98 on the great continents
Himlaya mts 27,000 ft
the ocean has never been actually sounded to a greater depth than 1 mile & 66 feet

North Carolina,                       24-1/2

Now 'pon my word, I'm not in fun,
You are your papa's finest son.
Campbell
8 d.

1832 property assessed $300
June 1st our neighborhood began to build a fort for their mutual defence against the Indians.  There is great alarm throughout this country. The Menominees together with the whites are going to drive the Soiux out of Illinois.  2nd received a visit from Messrs. Alvord Brand & Ursule D. Phelps.
June 8th a thousand soldiers crossing the prairie in sight on their way to the Indians country - 12th June finished planting corn.  June 18 rode 38 miles to salt creek 19th returned.
The Indians killed some persons near Henepin where the army is stationed. 21st began hoeing corn.
July 1st Father cut a severe wound on his hand. Had a considerable difficulty in stopping the blood.
2nd July had a meal of string beans. heard of Indians on crow creek.
Pheasant Grove turns out to protect the frontier.  We let one of our horses go into the service. very dry time.
6th July finished hoeing corn 2nd time, our horse returned.
12th July. The first cucumbers.  16th Began harvesting wheat. 17th bees swarm.   22nd July a northeast storm. there has been no rain of amount since May.
27th another fine rain.  2d August the army disbanded and passing by on the prairie.  12th sept. a the first frost (or post?). H.E. Burhans left here Sept. 25th common housekeeping.
27th Oct. 12th geese and ducks begin to fly.

14th Oct. the first killing frost
31st Oct set our orchard of Apple trees
6th Nov. a few flakes of snow the first this year - still very dry before this it has been warm and pleasant
10th saw Indians prisoners at Holland
Our corn all burnt up and 2000 ___
11th Nov. Mrs. Crosby buried.
18th a rain storm from the N.E. for some past. warm and pleasant and exceeding dry 26th sowed our lost ground to wheat
28th warm pleasant weather
yesterday killed a deer
1st Dec. a heavy rain storm. warm weather 
3d snow squall. ground white with snow
4th warm & pleasant
13th still very warm bees fly very thick.
14th a few flakes of snow
17th snow squalls pretty cold - sent letter to H.E. Burhans
20th Dec. severe cold weather
winter commenced in earnest
21st wild geese flying to the south
23rd warm and pleasant
25th went to Pleasant Grove to church
26th still very warm
1st Jan. 1833 very warm. Rainy 
7th cool the grass appears green. it has grown in some places 2 or 3 inches.
9th 10th snow squalls severe cold. nearly as cold as any time last winter.
[upside down text: Seventy five minutes enter tree "Why you no keep watch yourself - not trouble Gentleman]

1833
15th Jan. snow storm 4 inches
the first sleighing
16th severe cold
17th sent a letter to H.E.B.
24th the viewers finished their duty and promise to return a favorable report to the Co. Comm___ Court of a road from Pekin to Holland.
27th warm and pleasant
5th Feb. first wild geese seen
the road surveyed through
9th extremely warm and pleasant.
10th cool
11th hail and a snow storm from the North east - 3 in deep
23rd Feb. snow storm 4 or 5 inches deep yesterday Father killed a buck
1st March very cold the night the coldest this winter good sledding
5th another snow storm rec'd letter from D. Phelps, yesterday from J.M. Spencer H.E. Burhans, I Alond, RE Burhans
7th sent letter to REBurhans
14th sent letters to D PHelps HEBurhans I Alond(?)
21st Mr. sowed onion & beets & peas - digging my well
23rd Darius killed an eagle measuring 6 ft. 11 in. from tip to tip. get more locust trees
27th Mr. sowed oats, the ground dusty and still keeps extremely dry and quite cool. grass gust begins to start
28 dr__ stones for my well
Last Monday 25th began ploughing 
1st April clear warm dry smoky weather killed the first snake
2nd fine rain
3d began to set post and rail fence
6th planted early potatoes, brown corn etc. sweet corn. sowed sage seed. sweet corn up - last Thursday May 4th sowed flax seed
7th a fine rain storm
9th another fine rain.

10th news of 500 Indians embodied people begin to move off from the frontiers another war expected.
11th began planting corn and beans very heavy wind from S.W. at night shifted into the N.W. and a snow squall to whiten the ground - 
20th extremely dry - every now and then news of the expected war with the Indians
22nd began planting corn on the old land. great want of rain - 
26th the alarm of the Indian war subsided some appearance of rain but all signs fail
27th fine rain last night. 
28th O__ ____ has a calf
30th Apr. rye begins to head out - a very growing time.
1st May received a letter from H.E. B[urhans] - 
5th received news of Crosby's death by drowning on the Illinois River
6th called to Pekin on the Grand Jury found a bill of perjury against a man. a case of larceny suspici__d found no bill - 
7th found no bill against Miles Holcomb etc of murder of Funk
8th a bill of perjury presented but failed two other presentments made by failed of marking hogs of setting fire in the prairie another of threats of killing discharged by the judge and returned home.  Then one of the girls who were prisoners among the Indians last spring stood at fathers - very dry
16th began ploughing out corn and hoeing
19th a fine shower
20th another shower - pick the first ripe strawberries.
22nd property assessed 350 dols.
24th a fine rain
26th another considerable rain
28 = a rain storm encouraging times
1st June - a very heavy rain etc.
4th began planting field potatoes.

6th heavy rain
11th fine growing time. Rec'd letters from E. Van Horn & J. Alrond
15th June finished planting corn. Had the first new potatoes
17th hurricane with hail. took the roof from some buildings.  furns to the ground etc.
19th first cucumbers plenty of rain fine growing time
26th June began harvesting rye
1st July - last night a very heavy rain  rain every few days.
4th July - picked cucumbers - finished breaking prairie in the large field - handsome weather
6th Mrs. Margart arrived
8th began harvesting wheat etc.
14th first green corn
18th harvested oats
22nd finished harvesting wheat eat the first muskmelon 
July 31st began stacking wheat
7th Aug. finished stacking wheat
13th began haying
23rd began harvesting corn
6th Sept. a N.E. storm
11th began sowing wheat
20th Wild geese first begin to fly to the south
22nd first frost
1st Oct. very cool and very high winds
3rd cut buckwheat
4th killing frost
20th Oct first snow squalls
22nd prairie burned over
31st Father started for Morgan
1st Nov. pleasant smoky weather worked on the roads
4th sowed rye
5th sowed the last wheat
25 Nov. air rich of snow

1834
1st Dec. warm pleasant weather
11th Dec. warm and pleasant
J. B. R born s 11
1 h 1 hi etc -----------------------
18th snow squalls -------------------------
Dec. 24th Mitchell agrees to pay a town lot in Pekin the chain of 8 near the slough or on opposite Morgans
1st Jan. 1834 very severe cold weather. I.B. married about 6 inches of snow fell 2nd severe(?) winter weather
1st Feb. appearance of a storm, good sledding
14th before this for two weeks warm pleasant weather
15th a heavy N.E. rain --------------------
17th wild geese and ducks begin to fly very warm beautiful weather-------
23rd so on to the end of the month cold now weather now and then a snow squall
1st March cold snow squally day
4th Mar. went to Babys Grove __nition severe
7th rode to Ottaway returned to the vermilion
9th returned home 65 miles to Ottaway
13th rode Luriston Fulton county 50 miles 14 returned home - purchased a thrashing machine finished husking corn - 
19th & 20th a heavy N.E. storm of rain hail + snow, thunder etc.
24th snow storm  25th morning snow 2-1;2 in. deep a real winters morning.

1st Apr. very heavy rain streams very high
3d Apr got a deed of a building lot of Father. sold a yoke of oxen for $50.00
4th April ___ starts for Morgan county from Pekin in the morning 
8th let $50.00 to C___ Z____ made garden
9th ploughed garden etc.
12th began ploughing for corn
14th sowed flax seed - yesterday Uncle Darius moved here
21 and 22 very heavy rain with thunder. the ground full of water but little ground ploughed for planting. when we can plant we know not,
25th another rain storm. plenty of water any where
27th last night froze water etc a heavy frost most etc plums are all now
29th another rain storm.
4th let Wood have 10 bu corn at 20 c.b, bu potatoes at a shilling - $1.00 $3.00
white face heifer colored
5th another rain
9th May - frost
10th sowed the remainder of Barley - began sowing oats
13th another frost
14th another very heavy frost now everything that frost can kill is dead
began planting corn
15 - 16 - 17th frosts
27th April. in Kentucky it froze across streams and am/we(?) ___ plans it would bear a horse. the leaves and twigs of trees all killed there - 
17th finistered promised(?) my house
23rd first swarm of bees ---
28th May raised my house cold blustering squally weather
29th same
3rd June planted potatoes
6th and 7th very hot
11th began hoeing corn

12th June property assessed $400.00
1st July a heavy rain storm
2nd pulled flax - began harvesting rye - cholera in Pekin 3 deaths
July 3d 6 deaths by cholera in Pekin one death in Peoria - began harvesting wheat -
July 4 - clear handsome morning - first string beans - put up 112 do__ wheat - first young potatoes
12th July finished harvesting wheat
18th had the first cucumbers
1st warm fine dry weather stacked our barley yesterday. had an attack of the cholera morbus 00 
Moved into my new house on 10th Aug. extremely dry weather about these days
29th returned from Canton ___R___C
1st Sept extremely dry - obliged to dig for water for the cattle
8th R J/T(?)
10th Sept. first frost severe killing
got our Thrashing Machine
Sunday 21st clear and fine after a shower last night _____ left
Sept. 25th Ambrose married
28th Last night a fine rain more than since last July G. left
30th Sept. heavy rain springs almost dry before
1st Oct. high winds 
18th fire come on us last night burnt some rails and our shack of corn also a heavy thunder shower and a gale to day very cold took up on trees - flurries of snow

Nov. 11 began husking corn. yesterday a rain storm fine pleasant weather for several week.
1st Dec. killed hogs 13 in no.
2nd snow squalls
8th last snow squalls all night turned quite cold winder sit in
10th put me up a hovel. Wilton commissioned(?) his school
11th Lurius Birthday - heifer calved
1835
1st Jan. fine beautiful weather
Sunday 4th M. B. convened house Mr. Boscorn preached at my house.
Jan. 18th this evening Mary took a course of ___ - very sick Lurris been sick for a week past the influenza prevails throughout the country - I have a touch of it my self
21st called Doctor D. - Mary is not expected to live
23rd Mary's health better the ___ give encouragement a very sickly time throughout the country.  The influenza
25th last night a heavy rain extremely muddy
30th Jan. snow storm the first this winter - nothing but snow squalls before
1st Feb. clear cold winter weather yesterday started our thrashing machine
6th severe cold weather since the 1st
7th began to moderate

25th severe cold weather again last night the weather changed from warm to very cold and blustery in 5 minutes
1st March more moderate. Feb. left us very cld.
2nd began hewing timber for Campbells
266 ft. at 5cts. per foot -------$13.30
7th took a job of Mr. Campbell of 25.00 rails to be delivered on his land at $2.00 per hundred -- received payment $50.00
9th began getting out rails
last friday delivered J. Christman fee 21 bu 57 lbs
on saturday delivered to J.W. Croin 19 bu 50 lbs
today delivered to Christman 24 bu. 39 lb.
17th Tuesday March started for Springfield horse sick - staid at Musicks 
18 horse much worse left him and went in on foot - entered two lots 
19th came to Gridleys
29th came home
21st bought my clock am to pay it full $15.00 1st Dec.
heavy driving snow storm 
14 in Tuesday 24 K. rt cow died - commissioned work for Campbell at $1.25 per day
Thursday 26th snow all gone
Saturday 28th - sawed boards for Ambrose
worked 2 days for C.___K left with B.
Monday 30th K rt.
1st Apr. very warm - 1 days work for Campbell
5th set out my orchard
8th R. moved into Front Room  worked for Campbell.
8 days - set out Balm of Gilead trees

1835
11th Apr began ploughing for corn ploughed my garden
12th and 13th very cold for the season water froze 1/4 in thick
16th ground white with snow
last monday delivered Cram the remainder of the 50-1/4 bu. wheat. Ambrose got his things to keep house with
19th raised Mr. Kellogg & Mr. Campbell house  made garden. have a bad swelling under my arm it began a week last saturday.
Tuesday 26 worked 1-1/2 day for Campbell. 
25th very cold and saw sour weather looks like a storm. it finally turns out a very stormy day of hail snow and a great deal of rain
1/2 day for Kellogg
27th frosty mornings  sowed flax  planted potatoes
30th commissioners meet to locate the county seat - began planting corn.
May 1st fine warm weather grass 2 or 3 in. high  some trees just begin to leave out
1st very warm weather worked for Kellogg & Campbells 1/2 each - one of our oxen died today.
May 3d sunday a heavy hail storm as large as muskit balls lightning struck a black oat tree near the bridge between my house and Fathers
5th on the petit joury at Pekin
Trial between Ephraim Stout and Amass Stout who claims 200 dollars verdict for defendant.
GAC(?) between Snell & Om claims 400 dollars verdict for def.

1835
7th jury discharged
10th heavy frost
20th first sallad(?). 
21st settled with F.H. Kellogg paid him 19.00 in board and money - settled with W. Campbell paid me 10.00 dollars.  11.00 due me
commissioned raising a slaughter house
21th Lurius fell into the spring and come very near drowning - a man buried just below Pekin who died of Cholera
22nd May a heavy hail storm broke 17 panes of glass for me
23rd May my cold born last night - 
1st went Pekin cholera in Beardstown & Alton and is expected in Pekin. roads very bad uncommon wet rainy weather
3rd laid my front room floor
4th June Father gone to Alvords began working on the roads
12th finished planting potatoes  heavy thunder showers - every thing full of water cannot plough our corn. rather discouraging times
15h June finished drawing Campbells rails
16th heavy thunder shower last night. Began hoeing potatoes and ploughing out corn yesterday
18th last night a very severe thunder shower.
20 June quite cool
21st this morning a white frost.  cucumbers set beans nearly large enough to eat.
25th very heavy shower water 2 ft deep in my cellar - continues extremely wet poor prospect of raising any wheat corn or any thing else
28th quite cool and chilly.

1st July. I now has the appearance of dry weather. hear that 10 our of 11 cases of cholera died at Ottawa. went to Pekin and not finished ploughing out corn the first time yet - cold night last
July 4th clear beautiful day had dry pretty weather for a week prospects are more favorable 
6th great many sick about at this time
8th had the first cucumbers
16th Mrs. Kellogg died
17th was buried in front of Father's house. last week and this very wet again now clear and pleasant
July 20 started for Springfield to enter Undle J. Robers farm
21st entered.
22d returned home  at black berries people bean to harvest out our rye
27th July began harvesting barley
28 began harvesting wheat very hot and sultry weather
Mr. F. started for Springfield
7th finished harvesting wheat - began pickling cucumbers for winter
18 began harvesting oats almost every family about the country are sick with fevers and ague and from the distressing times - several have died.
17th Mr. Shirtheff died.  Mr. Weston dies a few days ago.
20th Dact Griffette aged 64 died - almost every family about are sick, more sickness about than has been for these years together
21st a frost this morning
people begin to fear for their corn 
23 and 24 a rain storm.

1835
25th Ambrose has a son born 
began binding oats
31st began haying cool night
1st Sept. Mr. Potter & wife came a visiting
2nd Isaac Waters died A. 55 at Peoria
3 - Mr. Bacon from Cincinnati came here
8th Mr. Bacon left here
7th began tacking our wheat  finished haying
8 rained.  a letter from Robert Ferguson dated July 9th
13th Doct. Davison wife died gathered plums crab apples grapes
17th convenes (?) our equinoctial storm
18th steady rain since yesterday morning - 2 days
19th County Seat located at Fremont
21st began cutting up corn
22nd finished [cutting up corn, probably]
23rd first killing frost. froze in cut (?) Mr. R. corn 
24th set up our corn
1st Oct Mr. Farnham left for Cincinnati - I am working for Campbells
2nd drove our hogs home from Pekin 30 in number
5th sleet fell today quite cold
6th a State road surveyed from Peoria by my house to Mackinaw Town Bloomington
8th began to burn prairie finished work ab C - 9 days
10th began ploughing for wheat pulled onions pleasant weather for two days past
29th Oct. began sowing wheat
1st Nov. fine weather yesterday took up our flax
7th Nov. finished digging potatoes
14th Mr. Kellogg left here for Atlas - went to Pekin to settle with Corga(?) fine weather
17th pulled turnips.

20th sleet-snow squall etc
began to lay the front room floor
wet fall - winter commenced in earnest
22nd Uncle Darius moved - towards evening it began to  snow from the N.E. fine and fast - 2-1.2 to 3 in.
23rd Bought a spotted brindle heifer of Crosby for $8.00 - 
2 cows - 2 heifers 4 steer - 1 colt
27th killed a buck
1st Decem. clear cold weather
3d warm muddy snow nearly all gone at night rain
4th cold snow squalls
8th Moderate thaws some
11th Larius' Birth day fine pleasant winter weather
13th Sunday - went to Mr. Rattiffes to meting
14th I killed Old Pomp - it was an act of mercy - nearly 30 yr. old
18th Darius returned from Springfield and entered ___ for Ambrose and for himself - husked Uncle Darius' corn (50 bu)
23rd - got a new breed of hogs of Hodgins - cold raw weather
24 snow storm turned to rain snow full 3 or 4 in. - began a sleigh  - yesterday Mary began spinning flax
1836
1st Jan. clear pleasant day went to Adams Mill with 55 bu wheat with Darius - turned over - got home in the night
Sunday 3rd - rained all night all day and the next night warm
frost coming east - mud, mud, muc
7th rained some every day since Sunday - warm and muddy
R. finished his stable

1836
7th continued(?) splitting rails - I killed a deer. finished cutting turnips - steam boats run up and down the r~
13th rec'd a letter from Mr. Combs of Cin. wishing me to come there offers $12.00 for week 
15th started for Cincinnati - went to Pekin a boat went down last night - very cold - doubtful if any more come up - returned home found Mary sick
16th very sick all day snow squalls last night - a considerable sickness in Hollands Gr. hear that the Canal bill has passed to borrow money on the court(?) of the state
17th Jan. Sunday, warm but turned cold
22nd severe cold weather freezes in our cellars. thrashed 40(90?) shacks of wheat to day
26th severe cold weather so cold that we did not pretend to work
1st Feb. extremely cold. beats everything so far. yesterday N__ Roberts froze his ear coming from Uncle Darius
2nd Candlemas day cloudy all day snow squally - thrashed wheat
3rd finished thrashing old wheat
6th snow fell 1/2 in. moderate after a long severe cold time
8th Settled with Broderick owe hims 15.85 cts 
11th snow then a sleet then a rain storm finally snow from 2-1/2 to 3 in.
13th made a sleigh
15th warm at night snow squalls 
16th snow storm - snow now 3 in. deep
20th rain - snow all gone
21st went to the saw mills for lumber
very muddy - frost coming out
23rd turned cold ground white with snow
25th went to Adams mill very cold
26th cut rail timber belard(?) Abner Mitchell snow squalls last night. quite cold

1st March: clear high wind and severely cold - Ambrose gone to Springfield
3d warm and pleasant yesterday we were driven off entered land splitting rails we lost 500 rails and logs enough to make 500 more 
4th very sever cold
6th snow storm
8th snow squalls finally turns into a rain storm made 3465 rails flour fill to 7-1/2 dollars per barrel.
10th very cold
11th still colder - too cold to be out at work - wind N.W. clear
13th Sunday snow storms last night 2 in. at night nearly all gone
16th last night it hailed rained & snowed before night snow and hail all and the stream very high. Father & Homer went to Hollands Grove with the sleigh
18th began thrashing wheat again heard cranes saw pidgeons yesterday
19th snow squalls last night
21st snow squalls quite cold high winds N.W.
22d last night snapping cold every thing froze solid - very cold all day - thrashed oats - emigrants begin to come up the river. Tharp arrived from N. Orleans
23d - clear warm, spring day
26th clear warm beautiful weather & the frost coming out then getting dry
31st Mar. went to Fremont got a morgage of J. Durnam as security for 200.00 dollars very muddy last night a heavy rain 
1st Apr. warm, grass begins to start day before yesterday Mr. Farnham arrived from Cincinnati. cleared out my cellar
Apr. 3d Father lost a cow (Geath)
5th Began to plough garden - warm beautiful weather
7th sowed onions
8th sultry weather - thunders all day at night it rained powerfully with heavy thunder & lightning began ploughing for spring wheat
9th hail rain & snow at night ground white with snow. it the ground quite hard - froze hard in the house - night before last I had 11 hens killed on the roost by a mink

12th cold month E. storm high chilly wind - had 3 more hens killed
13th cold rainy misty day set out my maple tins had 7 more hens killed, come very near killing the mink drove him under the house.
15th snow squall in the morning but a fine day
19th sowed spring wheat - cattle began to live grass but just hgith enough to let the cattle get a bite - drew my lumber from the mill to day. Yesterday of Mr. Owwns died - buried today - F___ left for Jacksonville 20 rt.
22nd last night a dreadful storm of rain wind thunder and lightning cold wind N.W. misty day
began to plough my garden yesterday but too wet another rain on top of it
23rd white frost, but clear
26 finished ploughing my garden
27 made garden
29th fine growing time pleasant showers. spring wheat and Barley up
1st May warm showery weather
2nd cut my thumb very bad. shall be laid up for some time - begun ploughing for corn - rain almost every day very wet
4th H & E B arrive from N.Y.
9th a little frost sale of town lots in Fremont
10-frost not enough to injure any thing
11th viewed the ground for a road Groveland to the Fremont & Washington road - warm dry weather
12 planted potatoes
13th began planting corn - dry time
19th fine showers the first for more than 2 weeks
24th May went to Peoria cold misty wet weather about these days
25 ditto. oh dear how chilly
26th finished planting corn in the big field
27th planted the orchard - fine weather again
30th began booking (?) prairie
3 - finished planting beans and potatoes. got a barrel of molasses house

1836
6th [June] Began thrashing wheat
8th Mr. Kellogg left here for the cost - paid for board $37.50 cts
9th Romanda married - a fine shower at night
10th went to Washington to see a caravan
14th began hoeing potatoes
15th began ploughing out corn - corn looks well - cut worms trouble us very much
Sunday 19th heavy rain.
K.E. Burhans and Lady arrived
23rd got my calf home
29th finished hoeing corn in the big field. F__ left here
1st July finished hoeing corn
10th took up Bagleys note
12 Farnham moved to Peoria
19th finished ploughing out corn - fine growing time 
20 July - began harvesting Barley
26th began harvesting oats
27th began harvesting wheat
8th began ploughing for wheat
19th finished stacking grain campmating(?) command near Mr. Ratliffe's
22nd rain storm
24th finished haying - very sickly in Pekin
26th rec'd the first Pekin Paper Dated 20th July No. 8
20th went after Plums & grapes - fine growing weather - getting out siding for the waggon house
30th Aug. snowed [sowed] peas and late oats pulled field beans
3d Sept finished stacking hay thrashed peas
11th went to the Urarulion(?) a visiting
14th visited the starved rock and Ottawa
16th returned home - wet rainy time
20th began cutting up corn
21 another rain storm uncommon wet time
22nd continues raining very hard
29th Sept. first frost fine weather
1st Oct. fine weather, afternoon heavy thunder showers.

1836
3d Oct - cold wind - cut up corn in the orchard began digging potatoes - potatoes rotten in the hill at night snow squalls of round flecks - 
4th Ice froze 3/8 of an inch thick ground froze hard
6th another heavy rain storm every thing spoiling
10th finished setting up corn - and thrashing beans fine weather for business Kelly & ___ left here yesterday
12th began thrashing buckwheat
17th Oct. a hard freeze - cleaned buckwheat - dry potatoes - began to burn around our fields
19th heavy rain - turns cold snows at night ground white with snow very cold winter's night - begun shaving shingles. killed a hog
20th clear winters morning - frost on the windows - unparalleled
23rd warm and pleasant
24th sent for Pastry cyclopedia - began pulling turnips - finished digging potatoes
25 took up F's note - paid my own money 1.18 cts
1st ____ fine weather about these days - covering turnips and making shingles
5th banked my house - pulled our onions - took a load of Buckwheat to mill
10th raised our waggon house 
11th a rainy night and day very warm
19 and 20 Nov. rain storm - warm - extremely muddy
22nd froze up from winter
24th sold a head of cattle for 170.00 dollars winter weather wild geese flying over. began to thrash barley
28th fine pleasant weather got a corn shiller(?) from Pekin.

1st Dec. finished putting on the siding on the waggon house.
Larius taken sick
2, 3 sick
4 better I was taken sick at night mary taken sick
5th myself better, mary very sick - rec'd a letter from J.K. Kellogg 2d
9th Dec. a rainy day - extremely muddy I husked corn for the hogs today
12th snow storm 6 in.
16th snow storm
17th snow squalls - snow drift - cold weather
18 Dec. turns worse. rains
10 rain until noon then it turns cold wind shifts in the N.W. and a severe cold strong blustery night frost bitten ears and fingers
24th warm again rains
25th cold again Christmas - clear cold day
26th coldest yet this winter
27th began killing hogs
28th finished killing hogs
1st Jan. 1837 - cold day fine sleighing
3d thrashed wheat - broke the dresses(?) of the thrashing machine - a very cold day
7th Ambrose has a son born had 5 deeds acknowledged
13th snow storm Henry starts for Rock River
14th put hay into the waggon house - snows yet about 12 in. deep
18 finished thrashing oats
19th finished clearing oats had 162 bu let Mr. Bacon have 6 bu 12qts corn
28 Jan. had a wolf hunt
Rec'd a letter from Kellogg dated Dec. 20
1st Feb. 1837, finished thrashing spring wheat - fine sleighing - yesterday warm day - today cold. Baron took 3 bbls corn on 6 bu. 12 qts
2nd finished thrashing wheat

2d Feb. let Mr. Bacon have 2 stacks corn - which makes 3 in all
7th went to Peoria and command miniature painting(?) drew two 8 drew two more 
12th went home - river very high
14th returned to Peoria river higher than I ever saw it. very cold. drew 2 miniature
15th weather more moderate
18th finished drawing miniatures at Peoria and made it in two weeks $81.00
27th turned cold - picking corn
1st March clear and pleasant froze very hard last night - finished drawing out the picked corn - finished picking corn yesterday
5th KEB returned from Ohio
7th now fall 2 or 3 inches cold weather
9th got my coat home from Campbells (business) husking corn 
13th went to  Peoria to instruct Mr. Nambin in Lithography - very cold
14th very cold morning returned home
15th thrashed grass seed
20th went to Pekin - got home the bbl sugar & molasses warm pleasant weather finished husking corn
21st rain storm - horrible travelling H.E. Burhans bought Joseph Ruck's fam for 2500 dollars 
24th very warm worked in shirt sleeves - Father sowed cabbage and lettuce seed
28th this morning ground white with snow - finished my garden from yesterday - Lot took 20 bu/pota.
29th cold night - froze quite hard in the house - clear morning - started for Springfield with H.E. Burhans
31th (30th?) snow hail and rain storm all day and most two nights streams all up and returned home and will try it again.
31 cleared off cold

1837
the Illinois higher then it has been for 6 years
Apr. 1st 1837 clear cold morning ground froze solid last night
2nd in the morning a little shower - cleared off warm
3 cold windy morning - froze in the house - started again for Springfield - did not.
5th went to Groveland 
6 rode to Springfield - rained all night
7th very muddy and misty
8th snow 2 or 3 in deep. In St. Louis on monday morning last
the 4th the snow fell 21 in deep - at Vandalia about 18 in.
9th clear and pleasant
10th pleasant
11th clear beautiful morning
12th returned home
15th began ploughing for spring wheat high drying wind
17th attended a funeral at the Yalis'(or Galis'). cold and snow squally
18th went to mill drew a load of lumber home began sowing spring wheat
20th began sowing Barley - white wormed my Apple trees
21st cold N.E. wind grass very backward
23d snow storm snow 3 in deep - taken with the quimery(?) soar throat - quite sick
25th sowed the first radishes 
26th finished sowing
27th Apr. ploughed my garden planted early potatoes and corn. began ploughing for corn
28th began planting corn - handsome weather
29th very warm day - went to Peoria - and tradedd.  Mr. Pranty commenced board
1st May - clear and cold froze in the house - frost - cold backward spring
2nd May made garden planted the first beans - melons beets etc
13th commenced planting corn in the field near Fathers house.
16th last night hail + rain this morning very near snow - between hail + snow quite raw and cold finished planting corn - plenty of rain
17th heavy frost it froze in double as thick as a window glass.

18th May another frost - replanted beans - leaves on locusts and walnut trees killed
19th another frost - hunted for my colt - cannot find him
20th another frost
22nd snow cold morning - poor prospects for corn - seed(?) corn fails generally throughout the country
23rd frost again - poor corn crops - Went to Pekin to view a road from Pekin to Washington
26th frost again - purchased a mare 9 years old for $50.00 saddle and bridle $5.00
31st May finished laying out a road from Pekin to Washington
1st June warm growing time - frequent showers
4th warm wet weather
5 June began hoeing corn
6th very heavy thunder shower  Mr. Kellogg arrive
7th Mr. Pranty left boarding here
Locusts getting very thick we fear that the will all our fruit trees
18th some want of rain
24th smoky days comm___ed (commenced/arrived?)
25th heard a steam boat very distinctly yesterday finished hoeing our corn the first time
1st July 1837 went with my family to the Menagerie and Circus at Washington
2nd Mr.s F. arrived board - yesterday sowed Buckwheat 
5th finished sowing Buckweat
4th of July attended a picknick party near Fremont
11th went to Peoria to draw miniatures
12th also at P. a -- made 12.00 dollar - very warm weather
17th began mowing our timothy
21st commenced(?) harvesting wheat but find it too green - we then build a shed for our waggons and finished it in the same day
25th began harvesting Barley
31st commenced in the oats(?)
1st Aug. fine weather rather dry
3d finished harvesting
4th comp meeting commenced at Mr. Ratliffs
11th commenced stacking grain
21st Miss Kellogg
22nd finished stacking grain
[stricken: 27th sending pay to the firm 25c]
week after this
24th Mr. Farnham has a son born
26th Miss Kellogg went home - 5 days. Mary's health no better.

1837
1st Sept. fine weather mowing grass and getting in wheat
12th first frost - drew in our prairie hay - began framing my wood house
14th began cutting up corn
19th a frost began drawing my brick(?)
20th another frost Rec'd of TJFarnham for board $11.87-1/2 cts
24th E left boarding here
25th rain storm - Mary quite sick
4th Oct finished digging potatoes - a lowry day
5gh last night it rained thundered and lightninged(?) nearly all night - the heaviest rain this year a most constant gleam of lightning all night
13 first killing frost
16th warm handsome weather Mary went to Fremont to stay a while
22nd wet and very warm weather - warm as july and continues so. fires begin to run on the prairie
23rd wind turns N.W. and cold after a long warm time
24th got 20 dollars of Riley(or Kelsy) E. Burhans cold fall wather
28th paid Campbell cool pleasant weather
1st Nov. warm beautiful weather Mary went to Fremont to stay this week
3rd made my mortar for plastering - warm smoky day
7th plastered my house
8 rain storm warm weather
14th still warm beautiful weather
20th killed my beef? buf? bees? extremely warm - thunder showers - I went bare footed
22nd last night it turned cold this morning winter weather ground white with snow
26th warm again
28th very wet snow high south wind.

29th Nov. clear and very warm day - went to Fremont to trade etc.
1st Dec. 1837 warm misty muddy day
8th hail and rain all day very wet the river higher than has been known since we lived in this country
9th squally and very muddy - went after Dr. Davidson for Mary
10th cold ground frozen extremely rough 
15th first snow fall about 6 in. turned up warm and rained
16th - 20th another snow storm fell about 8 in.
22nd last night a severe cold night clear and cold day
25th Christmas warm and pleasant south wind snow going
26 cool Dr. Davison called the 3rd time Mary quite low
31st Dr. Davidson& Dr. Wood held councel - and gave her refs.
1st Jan. 1838
warm weather frost coming out very muddy
7th Mary took the sacrament  snow squalls
8th Mr. Hitchcock called here, he was one of my scholars when I was 17 yrs. old - quite cold
15th Darius started after my stray cold in Schyler Co.
16th rain storm very warm weather about these days
Mary not expected to live long
22nd snow fell last 2 or 3 in.
Mary still failing
27th Durham ride___ the lot in Fremont in foreow(?) of us
28th wind shifted in the N.W. and snow squalls and severe cold night - one of my calves froze to death. Mary a little better
1st Feb. the coldest day this winter
Darius & Walter took the first load of Barly to Peoria - Mary getting better I am making a new cylinder
Feb. 5th settled at Groveland 
14th very cold 16 degrees below zero this morning
16th snow storm
21st 15 degrees below zero.

1838
22nd at night 20 degrees above Zero
Mr. Summons magnatried(?) Julia
16th Julia David came here
27 finished thrashing oats - begins to thaw soon
1st March - snow rain & hail storm. snow about 4 in. - went to Groveland
4th another snow storm - about 6 in.
5 quite warm and pleasant - Mary no better - boys boys drawing saw logs
Mar 31 - Thermometer to 84 degrees dry and very warm for 2 or 3 weeks past Mary very low 
Apr 1st beautiful weather grass green - cattle begin to pick a considerable
3 Began ploughing for
7 rain warm cattle live without feeding Mary very low still failing
10th cool squally weather froze the ground last night
16th Dreadful storm last night. heavy thunder 4 or 5 hail showers broke 2 panes of glass ground covered with hail as big as musket balls - went to Fremont to court - the Judge did not come
17th went again - Father's suit called but not tried. I am cleared - very high winds and cold
18th snow squalls all day dreary looking time
20th pleasant day
25th warm - extremely wet heavy thunder - brindle cow calved - 2 cows to be helped up - Mary no better
30th ploughed our gardens
1st May - rain storm - no sowing done yet late spring work
2nd rainy day - 
7 May began sowing barley quite cool weather
8th frost this morning
10th quite a heavy frost cold N.E. wind
12th warm pleasant
15 began planting potatoes
16the began planting corn
21st My colt born last night
22nd began planting corn in the big field
26th finished planting corn, began sowing oats
28th cold mornings
29th frost in the Gulphs(?)

1st June 1838 Went to Fremont with the _ials for stamping measures - finished sowing oats and Barley
7th raised Fathers and Ambrose's house every day great want of rain 
18th K.E. B and Minerva started for N.Y - frequent showers very warm fine growing time - ploughing out corn the first time - Mary not expected to live nong - 
27th last night a dreadful shower of rain with heavy thunder and a constant glare of lightning and wind
28th last night another but not quite so severe
3d July finished hoeing potatoes. grist celebration at groveland - on 4th
7th last night rec'd a letter from KEB. Mary had another bad spell 
10th began to have watchers Mary low
19th began harvesting wheat Mary had another convulsive fit
25th Began harvesting barley - extremely warm weather. Mary had the sacrament administered to day by Mr. Huntington.
30th July - Mary W. Roberts died my Dear Beloved wife with whom I have lived better than seven short years. Oh! what a vacancy how doleful? how ____ I am - she died in the triumph of ____. Blessed are the dead that die in the lord. she died between 12 & 1.
August 5 - Mind well Roberts died this morning between 3 & four in the morning.

17th camp Meeting convenes at Mr. Ratliffs
20th August Edina again commenced work
1st Sept. came to the school to serve God my remaining days. Attended a protracted meeting near pleasant Grove and there thank God I was enabled to take up my cross Oh! may this be the beginning of a new live in service of my Redeemer
2nd was received in to the church of Christ was baptised with Lurius - partook of the Lord's supper - Oh! it was the happiest time of my life May God give me grace to remain steadfast in the service of My Redeemer
5th winter set in snow storm
6th cold and snow squally
7 sleet put the mortar together for Father house
8th last night a cold winters night - this morning ice on the windows very cold. 5-1/2 above Zero.
9th coldest night since we lived in this country 3 degrees above Zero
10th - 10 degrees above Zero went after Walters & my strays
12th heavy rain storm - which we need very much - began plastering Father house
15th snow storm last night 1-1/2 in ___ oppression of winter K.E.B. came here
17th very cold 1 degree above Zero. got our strays advertised yesterday
21st Nov. H.E. Burhans family moved into my house
29th a Public prayer and thanksgiving - last I met with the trustees of the Pleasant Grove churches to make out the salary of our minister.

1st Dec.c took Margaret home. good travelling ground day
6th very cold
1-1/2 degrees below Zero - snow 1 in deep
20th cold 9 degrees below Zero 1 in snow
25th Christmas clear cold went wolf hunt saw none. went to Groveland I called on my acquaintances and at Mr. Huntington's as home - the boys had a party
26th 6 degrees below Zero - clear very dry great trouble for water
27th killed hogs
28 finished killing hogs snow storm
30th last after dark 7 degrees below Zero
1st Jan. 1839
A year ago my Dear Wife experienced religion - how happy was that house since that she has left me and gone to realms above to praise her god - how soon I shall follow the Lord only knows
5th attended a church meeting
6th Lowry day attended meeting sacrament administered felt my soul edified and comforted
7th finished husking corn for this year
10th very warm and muddy frost coming out of the ground
13th heavy rain storm the first one for a long time
14th still rains, I think that the river will rise
16th worked on the hill hear Hippoly's
17th finished working the hill - warm stormy muddy weather first Stem Boat up
18th still squally sent a load of Barly to Peoria - frost out of the ground
23rd finished thrashing Barley cool handsome weather 5-1/2 degrees above zero
Jan 31st made my debut at a debating society
1st Feb. drawing saw logs to Marberry's mill - paid John Mosby(?) 2.00 in full of his demands at night went to Fremont after Dr. Perkins for KEB child.

1839
7th cut barn logs, quite warm again at night attended the Ly___ again - I opened the debate - night before last I presented a line(?) etc.
15th wild geese flying over beautiful weather for business
17th Sunday night Mr. Huntington preached at _erman Castle's
18th started for the Vermilion - snow 2 in. deep staid at Bills on sow(?) creek
19th rode to Barley Point. visited my friends
20th rode back to bills was very sick in the night
21st arrived at home - travelling very bad - very warm 
22. thunder showers
23rd foggy warm morning
26th attended a temperance meeting and signed the pledge of Total abstinence
1st March - handsome day cleaned up oats
16th went to Peoria to an auction - came back over the bluff and bought some maple sugar
18th heavy N.E. storm with thunder & lightning hail etc.
20th another heavy N.E. storm cold severe for cattle - nearly finished hewing timber for our barn
29th Father went to Peoria - saw a woman drowned in the farm creek - killed 4 hogs our whole family have had distemper like a cold all getting better
1st warm handsome weather
3d began ploughing for spring wheat 
5th sowed onions
10th planted potatoes in the garden - hail storm
11th showery weather
11 Apr. bought a one horse carriage for 80.00 dollars - paid cash 15.00 dollars
18th Began sowing Barley - yesterday went to Peoria. drawing miniatures
27 sowed Buck wheat
1st May laid up fence by the sod fence - frequent showers - trees all leaved out
4th frost - 3 degrees below freezing -dreadful!!
7th painted Father's house
8th painted Ambrose house - My mare has a cold to day
14th began planting in the big field
16th finished planting corn

22nd May - the first ripe currants and strawberries - began hoeing Baden corn
29th went to Mr. Harris' to raise a barn - cool nights after a rainy spell. There will be wild fruit in abundance - also plenty of Peaches and apples where there are trees.
30th light frost - 
June 1st clear day went to capt. Water's 
2nd rode to church
3d rain
4 began ploughing out corn in the big field - also began ploughing for buckwheat
6th heavy rain
12th June 94 degrees in the sun wet time discouraging for corn
July 1st - beautiful weather - hoed potatoes
2nd went to Kelly Burkins raising
4 of July - attended a celebration at Washington about 600 joined the procession
14th began harvesting wheat. also began haying
22nd began harvesting barley - very hot
July 30th just one year today by dear wife died. how swift time flies. worked in the oat harvest
2nd August finished harvesting
5th Election day went to Fremont then to Groveland
6th commenced stacking our grain
28t went to a church meeting prepatory to a prostrated(protracted?) meeting
30th bought one lumber waggon and double harness of Warren Willard and gave my note for 85.00 dollars payable one year from date. and rec'd one cow and calf and a Burcan in security for the payment for the use of the waggon etc
31st Aug. - got license to marry - attended a protraction(?) meeting
1st Sept. very dry - first frost
6th Married Miss Anne Waters
8th Again commenced house keeping. Oh! may my enjoyment be as happy as I anticipate - May our lives be wholly devoted to God.
26th first killing frost - digging potatoes

1839
2nd October - visited my Father in lows
3 Father took Julian to Peoria to Dr. Livingston - warm beautiful weather
15th began thrashing Buckwheat - finished topping out my chimney - warm weather
25th last night thunder showers - to day extremely warm - so thick I work without my vest - framing my stable
5th heavy rain storm. wind shifted N.W. cold at night snow squalls for the first
7th ground frozen for the first
11th commenced picking corn
23d Nov. snow storm
25th severely cold 11 degrees below Zero - good sleighing 
28th cloudy and foggy at night
29th very foggy 
30th continues very foggy
1st Dec. towards noon the fog arose but cloudy and damp trees loaded with ice a long gloomy time
2nd snow squalls disagreeable weather
Dec. 4th began ploughing 
5 finished picking corn and engaged all our corn to Davy Shurtz for 25 cts per bu.
6th started two teams ploughing
13th snow storm came as fast as I ever saw it - its full 4 or 5 in. 
15th Sunday went to Ambroses to meeting on my sled
18th 8 degrees below Zero. Brow and Margaret came here.
24th thrashed oats - appearance of a storm
25th Christmas attended church - after sermon by Rev. E.S. Huntington Dr. Davidson delivered a lecture on temperance - and I was appointed vice president of the society - went to Father Waters. took supper in the evening visited Mr. Marsh came home and got lost on the prairie it being foggy and no road - wandered about 2 hours or upwards - the horse nearly tired out finally the moon arose which enabled me to tell where east was I then after a long while came on a road which lead me home at nearly 1 oclock
26th killed hogs
27th cold
28th severe cold day.

31st Dec. sold a cow at Peoria for $20.00
1st Jan. 1840 fine sleighing we thrashed oats
4th & 5th warm appearance of a thaw
15th Jan. 4 degrees below Zero yesterday father and I drew in corn
24th 7 degrees below Zero. took two loads of Barley to Peoria - paid off Farrell
25th 14 degrees below Zero - this is going it
Feb. 1st cold weather
5th warm south wind finished thrashing rye
19th Mar. Walter B. Roberts married to Mary Holloway - cool day
24th ground white with snow
28th Raised our Barn - without any accident - cloudy all day - last night a heavy rain
29th snow squalls 
30th Worked on Mr. Browns house cold snow squally day
7th Set out 25 grafted apple trees - wind shifted into the south after blowing from the N.E. a long time and cold too
9th last night a heavy rain storm - with thunder and lightning - grass grows finely - sowed onions - at night heavy shower with some hail and heavy thunder
17th Frequent thunder showers - framing Walters house
18th Eliza Tarbell buried
22nd planted my garden
23rd finished sowing barley - shingling Walters house
24th a son of Mr. Richmond committed suicide by cutting his throat in Fremont
27th heavy frost killed locust leaves
29th finished putting the siding on Waters House - ploughing for corn - yesterday sowed oats.
Apr. 30th frost this morning - cleared up wheat
May 2nd went to Peoria to trade
3rd heavy rain storm and heavy wind. fences blown down
5th frost this morning. Mr. Campbell raises his Barn -- 
10th frost
11th frost
12th frost began to paint the inside of my house
13th began planting corn
16th planted potatoes
17th A__ foes gathered and broke (?)

3d June 1840 Grand state convention at Sprinfield of the Why ________
4th rain with thunder etc
6th Henry paid for the waggon
7th a little frost this morning the Chicago delegation at Fremont there wee about 16000 persons in Springfield 
8th began plowing out corn - we are putting shingles on the Barn
20th Fence finished  shingling the Barn, and finished ploughing out the corn the second time we fear our large field of wheat is struck with the rust - quite dry
21st a heavy thunder shower last night
26th thunder shower with a gale - our grain all blown down trees down too
28th heavy thunder shower with another gale - and a constant gleam of lightning - yet God preserved us through. Our wheat 50 acres all struck with the rusk and ruinded - great loss
1st July ploughing out corn the 3d time appearance of rain
4th July we all went to Washington to celebrate the day - a great many people - 500 ladies marched in the procession a free dinner
6th July commenced harvesting wheat we cut about 5 acres for seed from a field of 50 acres - worth nothing for flour - a great failure
24th July Paid a note of Willards 23.00 dollars
29th began hauling hay
30th commenced drawing in Barley first catydids in six weeks may be expected a frost which will be Sept. 10th
14th finished shingling the machine house - boys shelling corn plenty of ___ (noise?) about these days
Aug. 30th Rec'd a letter from H.E.B.

Sept. 5th 1840 rode to Bloomington with my wife - visited Henry J. Burhans - been married just 1 year to day
6th Sunday - forenoon attended a funeral for a child - a very good discourse by the Rev. drake. After noon discussion(?) on the authenticity of the scriptures
7th Returned home found all well as usual
12th went to Washington to church heard Bishop Waugh took dinner at Mr. Simmon's afternoon heard Mr. Tucker - a Baptist clergyman
15th Began cutting up corn  rain
16th heavy rain
18th first of any consequence not enough to kill any thing
4th Col. Mitchell died at Washington
6th Oct. finished drawing for B.W. Parker - charged him 8.00
9th sold H.E. Burhans 28 lb butter at 14__ amount 3.50 Dr.
13th Old Mr. Willard died - father drawing brick for Wallers house
22nd turned cold
23rd finished Simmons' Miniatures charged for 3 $7.50
24th finished Walters chimney 20 degrees above zero
25th went to church heard Mr. Thimble preach
26th 14 degrees above zero - very cold
7th Nov. plastered Walters house warm pleasant weather
1st Dec. 2 degrees above zero husked corn
9th birth day - pleasant and warm - husking corn on Ambrose's farm
14th Walter & I thrashed rye- warm foggy weather about these days
17th turned cold - after a warm spell
18th 1 degree below zero - clear.

26th snowed very fast
27th went to meeting and in the afternoon to the north school house
1st Jan. 1841 - clear and cold in the morning after noon snow squalls in the evening had a meeting at my house
2nd Jan. severe cold 9 degrees below Zero.
Sunday moderate with snow storm sacrimental day
4th went to Peoria
7th began thrashing barly
11th Went to Peorie with a load of Barley - crossed on the ice
13th Wednesday Harry came here to board
14th began dawing saw logs to Moobry's Mill
17th clear and severely cold 20 degrees below zero
18th 22 degrees below zero colder than it has been since we lived in the state
1st Feb. went to Fremont to court - stormy and unpleasant in the way  went to HE Burhans visiting snow squall
9th turned cold preaching by Mr. Huntington at Fathers
12th 14 degrees below zero
11th cold still
12th cold
13th no better - three days no work done
19th went to  Washington and finished 3 miniatures and began 5 more
20th went to Church and 21 persons came forward for examination and admission to the church
28th communion season about 27 persons were renewed(?) with the church - a season of great interest
1st Mar. pleasant weather, went to Fremont as a witness
4th singing(?) school(?) at my house, snow storm
5th snow
7th snow nearly all day
8 pleasant
10th went into Mud creek settlement with a pitcher (picture?)
14th Mar. 1841 Charles Clark buried

19th Mar. making nails - Father went to Peoria - at night it began to rain the first rain storm for a great while.
26th Mar. 1841 Robert Anderson buried. was married about 6 weeks since - heavy thunder storm Walter ploughed his garden - I set out some shrubbery
27th quarterly meeting at Pekin - mowed hazel patch in calf pasture after noon very heavy showers, cellar 1-1/2 ft water in it
6th went to James Ayres & L__ Harris to notify them of their appointment - as Trustees of school board
7th split stakes for the school section
8th Began sowing wheat; surveyed the school section
9th went on the school section and valued it by 40 acre lots
10th snow storm - winter weather have had a severe cough for 3 days
11 sunday ground still white with snow cold backward spring
Apr. 9th went to Washington came back in the rain - Papers in mourning for the death of President Harrison - second(?) sowed(?) of five(?) few(?) garden peas & lettuce
22nd ploughed my garden & planted potatoes - cold backward spring - cattle can just live without feeding
24th heard the first Whipporwills
25th Mr. Huntington's health poor -asks for a discharge  quite warm
26th cold N.W. wind - sowing Barly
29th Apr. last night and today a heavy rain storm high winds and cold.
1st May 1841 frost and clear and cool went to preperatory lecture
3d went to Pekin to trade cold chilly wind
4th another rain storm cold and wet backward spring discouraging - to farmers
8th frost - some ice. pleasant day. piled up my lumber at Mooberry's mill
10th went to Robin's mill showery day hail storm on my way home.

12th frost this morning - yesterday began ploughing for corn - and finished sowing Barley
14th frost +ice again - By proclamation of the vice president _____ and prayer throughout the U.States --- attended church a prayer meeting
15th frost and ice
19th began planting corn - yesterday planted castor Beans - warm pleasant weather
25th attended a Temperance meeting- and address by Mr. Nolans(?) - after which a lecture on abolition by the Rev. Mr. Allen of Alabama
June 7th began ploughing corn - fine growing time
30th June - began ploughing corn 2nd time stacking - hay
1st July finished ploughing out my orchard
4th July went to Pekin had a free dinner - oration by H. Hatch - great con____ of people
3d Aug. started for Chicago on a visit stopped of Mr. Moss' next day went to Mr. Grooms next day to Mr. Potters.
5th went to Mr. Alvards  started for Joseph Grooms on Fox River 45 miles from Ottawa to Georgetown 18 miles to Grand 12 mi.
11th started for Chicago clear and very dusty - yesterday Smith Minkler and I went to Yorkville on the Fox river county seat of (blank) crossed the river into Bristol then up the river through a beautiful country a few miles then crossed again and returned.

1841
arrived at Chicago a little before night. stopped on the lake shore at Mr. Cooks. Beautiful prospect
12th took a view of Chicago saw the old fort Dearborn
13th thunder storm from off the Lake
14th Rode to Elk Grove 20 miles N.W.
15th Sunday. Thunder storm. I am threatened with a fever feel quite unwell.
16th fell better handsome morning
17th went to Dundee found Uncle Josiah's family well
18th visited with them
19th  rode to J. Groom's through a beautiful country
20th rode to Mr. Alvords showery all day
21st rainy in forenoon
22nd went to church at Lowell at night went to Mr. Bettus
23d visited the Starved rock and Deer Park
24th came home and found Darius sick with the Billious fever
1st Sept. went to Peoria - extremely dry - drying that it has been for seven years
8th began cutting up corn - ripe husks dry on the ear - springs all dry - wells nearly so
11th first frost - Cook and wife visiting here
18th Sept. sent for the Northern Light
23rd finished cutting up corn had a fine rain storm and a long cloudy time
Sept. 27th meeting to Incorporate and elect trustees - I am chosen one - rainy day
28th went to Peoria to trade
29th general training in Fremont
11th Monday - commenced laying out or reviewing so much of the Peoria and Mackinaw as this between Dan'l (or David?) Roberts and

Mackinaw Bridge
13th finished laying out the road - last week - I tore down and rebuilt my chimney
22nd cold windy weather went to Peoria with 3 hogs got (____?) for clov__(?) machine
25th this morning Thermometer down within 8 degrees of Zero - potatoes not all dry yet - yesterday prairie frozen for the first - wind shifted into the S. and blew hard - thrashed wheat from Messenger and killed 2 hog for prairie market
26th began working on Ambrose's A___bs floor
12th went to Fremont - left a brand with Manson for Thomas Bullock
13th went to Washington to attend a meeting of the trustees of Town(ship?) 26 N. for unity two districts for a school this winter
24th-25th heavy N.E. storm rain hail and snow - a furious storm
26th went to  Washington with Uncle Ichabod - 4 or 5 in. snow - went with a cutter - In the evening went to Deacon's Bascous(?) visiting
1 Dec. Charles Waters visited here - I was taken sick with a severe cold or the winter fever
3rd rain storm - warmer
4th turns cold high winds
5 - H.B. Watters married
10th very sick vomiting all day and night
11th some better
12th sunday Harry & Emil came to see me Father Waters staid here all night last
14th went to Fremont got license for Darius to be married.
15th Darius P. Roberts married to Augusta Hathaway by R. A. Moffat rainy and muddy - don't mention it
16th turned cold snow squalls cloudy
17 - barn up at last - very rough - got the horses shod
22nd began hailing in the night and continued till about 8 or 9 oclock then commenced rain and hail and continued all day and a great part of the night without ceasing.

23rd went to Father Waters - and to Fremont - got map of county to make(?)  horse got loose came home by Chertus(?) Waters and Father Waters hard traveling on the ice - very hard - bridges gone very high water
26th went to Fremont found the horse etc.
1st Jan. 1842
Went to Fremont with grass seed and flax seed 62-1/2 per bu. for 4 bu. grass seek locking 2 qts 2.50 per bu. - visited Harry Waters south wind. thosos(?) quite muddy
2nd sunday went to Washington to churge - quite cold
3d met with the Trustees at Mr. Sills - snow squalls
5th visited Cyrus 
6th warm south wind
9th Old Mr. Ayns dead and burr[ied]
12th school master of the P. Murtagh has died last night
[FEB?] 8th very cold 12 degrees below Zero
10th 11th warm - drawing Barley to P___
14th cold again
March 1st very warm and extremely muddy - grass begins to grow wheat looks green and begins to grow - yesterday attended an abolition caucus was nominated for a representative to the state Legislature with Esqs.(?) Woodrow
20th Mar. went to Fremont to hear Eld. Chose preach on Aub(?) abolition
21st began ploughing - set out apple and peach trees - grass quite green - apple trees having

25th peach trees in bloom
29th went to Coleman's nursery - got 2 pear trees a flowering locust and the black Tuscan Rose and the Incomparable Rose
30th went there again and get the yellow & white rose - and 3 kinds of Raspberrys
31st went to mill - got cedar trees etc.
11th planted my garden fine growing time - very early spring - some of our neighbors planted corn the 29th of March
21st Apr began planting corn and castor beans - fine prospect for peaches and apples
28th frost - killing - 7 degrees below freezing  fruit all killed on the low ground
1st May - Norm(?) R. returned from Natches
4th May - frost - cool weather
6th heavy frost
7th cool weather about these days - Abolition quarterly meeting in Washington
20th the Mob(?) took possession of the presbyterian church hinder by Eldr Chose and Moffat Gorin(?). Buster etc. with swearing ruffians with clubs at the door to keep out all the Abolitionists - we left Washington went to Pheasant Grove - had a discourse from Mr. Lovejoy and Dickey - 15 or 20 joined the society - es  rainy for several days
28 May 1842 - our property assessed - by Mr. Davis
horses $275     98 acres at $6. JMR [John Roberts]
cattle $265.00    80 acres at $6 - ABR [Ambrose Roberts]
clocks $35.00     80 acres at 8 - DR [Darius Roberts]
carriages 60.00  the remainder 3 _____
waggons  50.00
hogs    25.00
other property 200.00

1842 
1st June - harrowing corn - framing Darius' house
4th John Anderson raised his barn - very rainy wet time
11th cool weather - bad corn weather
4 degrees above freezing
20th Sun(?) - frost this morning - walling up Father's cellar
21st Doct. Syman came up on a visit
27th saw Martin Van Buren in Peoria last week Lind(?) Morpith passed up the prairie toward Chicago
4th July Graced(?) free dinner in Fremont - Mr. Kellogg orator best I  ever heard
15th began harvesting - dry and warm
7th Oct.[Sept?] 1842 Capt. Brown & Mr. Shirtliff buried
10th Cousin Olive Phelps buried - first killing frost on the 9th Oct. quite dry and dusty
Sept. 5th Abolition meeting at Delevan after a long dry warm beautiful time it commenced raining A Black brought here bound for Canada
12th after a week of rainy cloudy snowy weather it cleared off with about 4 in snow on the ground
15th snow again 1 in.
16th went to Peoria at night it commenced snowing - it fell 4 or 5 in.
17th high winds - snow drifts severe cold winter in earnest
18th severely cold night - several hens froze to death - only 2 weeks ago it was warm dry smoky and pleasant what a change
27th continues severely cold - 10 degrees below zero this morning snow squall nearly every other day part of our loose seed and all ouf flax under the snow
19th snow storm 6 or 7 in deep
30th high winds - the largest snow drifts I have seen in the State. hunted hogs - roast turkey

1st Dec. 1842 - clear 2 degrees below zero
2d warm and pleasant after a long cold time
4th rain storm sunday heard 2 sermons one by Mr. Chapman the other by Uncle Lehan(?) Waters
9th My birth day - visit from Mother yesterday - this evening Mr. Chapman preached at Fathers - heavy sleet(?)
12th went to Fremont and to Charles made a visit - this is the tenth day it has been cloudy - ice on the trees and grass
16th fourteenth day cloudy continually 
17th cleared up pleasant moderate
21st went to Washington visited Mr. Willow growing cold ground solid - again
23rd 14 degrees below zero
24th visited Mr. Matthews
Jan 1st 1843 sacrament of the meeting house fine cold day
3d 10 degrees below zero
6th rain storm - muddy - turned to snow cold again
8th sunday 16 degrees below Zero
10th Tuesday - snow fell last night
11th Earthquake in Peoria, Fremont etc etc 6 or 7 am
12 Thurs snow fell again 12 or 15 in. again - hard winter
Bate(?) 20-1/2 lb Tallow at 10 ct per lb. payable when Miller pays the last amt due to us
15th Sun clear and pleasant warm
16th went to Peoria crossed on the ice warm and pleasant snow goes first
Bought 2 of Mason's sound hoop for Nelson H. Crosby and Uria N. Crosby at one dollar each - January thaw
20th still warm bare ground muddy
24th pleasant thrashed the remainder of our cloves and got in the last of our flax
25th commenced on our corn in the field

31st Jan. very cold windy blustery snowy day after a long pleasant time winter seems to have begun in earnest again. yesterday began running our clover chaff through the machine
1 Feb. cloudy good candlemas
3 and 4 Abolition meeting at Pleasant Grove - next meeting at Washington 2 May - next - snowstorm from N.E. 7 or 8 in. 
5th clear windy snow flies cold
6th 12 degrees below zero  15 degrees below at Washington 2 below the warmest to day - coldest day this winter - traded my boy colt for a cutter
7th 22 degrees below zero - some say 30 degrees ditto
8th went to Fremont
15th Feb. 12 degrees below zero - clear snow a few in deep
16th  7 degrees below zero - getting out clover seed only a 4 or 5 above through the day a long severe cold time
28 Feb. 2 degrees below zero went to Washington settled with Mr. Marsh
1st Mar 8 degrees below zero - severe beginning of spring
2nd 5 degrees below
3d 2 degrees above zero - Julia took cold
26th Feb. Wednesday after had a choking in the evening(?) watched with her - from that till she died we watched with her thursday night we sweat her soar throat and high fever Saturday morning 
4th sent for doctor sunday morning about 5 oclock she left this world for a better - we mourn her loss - Text at her funeral
Blessed are the dead that die in the lord.
11th at zero - continues very  cold
13th 4 degrees below zero
15th at Zero
20th very cold - sun dogs 2 degrees above Zero
23rd Mar very bright sun dogs extremely cold 4 degrees below zero

1843
24th Mar. 4 degrees below zero -wind changed into the S. after a long cold N.  to W winds at night snow storm - turns cold again
25th 3 degrees below zero
27th went to Adams Mill - it snowed all day untill in the night some time
28 wind N.W. ______(tolerably?) cold snow 6 or 8 in deep
29th snow storm again - fine sleighing
30th cold ____ ____ appearance of a storm - cattle dying for want of fodder in Wisconsin and Chicago - many nearly out about here - what shall we do without spring comes soon
Apr. 1st pleasant some appearance of spring - drew a load of wood on the snow
2nd cloudy and cool - appearance of a storm
4th went to Peoria - a few wild geese and ducks beginning to fly along the river - meadow larks begin to sing - heavy frosts
10th Frances Higgins funeral went to Ayers'
11th appearance of a storm. snow and ice not all gone yet - grass trim near fences begins to start a very little
13th went to Mackinaw - Ice still in the sloughs - first warm day this spring
21st began sowing spring wheat - last saturday went to Groveland took 76 lb flour to Barrows
25th went to Pekin yesterday Battallion training in Pekin - heavy thunder showers heavy wind - it unroofed 2 houses in Groveland - blew the fences down - very bad - went to the coal(?) bank with Burrows
26th rainy all day the cold winter cracked the bark on my apple trees - killed nearly all the peach trees
3rd May our folks went to Pekin
4th rain storm - no ploughing yet discouraging
10th May - began ploughing - too wet yet - went to Fremont - bought a diamond plough for 9.00 dollars cash
12th ploughed gardens Apple trees begin to blossom - also cherries tree
19th May Began planting corn - not half our ground ploughed yet however - yet it is so late we make a beginning everything feels one month later than usual
11th May 1843 commenced taking the Western Citizen

27th May 1843 - planting corn - began to rain - rain all day some in the night
28 snow showers - very high and cold wind from N.E.
1st June heavy frost - finished planting corn in my orchard - planted potatoes
2nd June finished planting potatoes and beans at night heavy thunder showers constant lightning hail etc.
3d misty N.E. wind
4th last(?) heavy thunder showers all night everything full of water
5-6-7 Appearance of rain went to Peoria get a bbl sugar of Miller on his book charged is $16.56
8th-9th threaten rain few sprinklings of rain - no oats sowed yet
11th heavy frost - poor prospect for corn etc. pr___ rising clear after a long cloudy rainy time
Alex B. Davis assessor
