15th heavy rain again
16th appearance of rain
17th clear and cool - began working corn
1st July clear warm morning - corn grows rapidly - heard a strange noise in the N.W. school meeting to day
4th July - no celebration marer(?) this Season(?)
7th began haying - dry handsome weather
18th finished ploughing out corn -  want of rain
20th got the hay up to the big barn
21st worked on the roads
22nd  ditto
31st July began harvesting - great drought
3 Aug - Father and I went to Peoria - quite sickly there Augusta had a doctor most all of us sick with it influenzs - extremely dry and warm - corn withering up - discouraging prospects for corn.
7th Election - vote taken for moving a county seat
15th Rec'd. of Robert Roberts 65.00
16th finished haying
26th finished cutting clover seed.

2 Sept - went to Fremont - and to church meeting at Pleasant Grove - paid partly for my magazine
4th sent fee the 4 last Nos. of the Magazine - very warm for several day past
5 had some meshing(wedding?) cake
10 northeast storm
24 attended Sarah Birkett's funeral - last week and a part of this week Dr. T. Underhill lectured on Animal Magnetism in Fremont
25 eat an apple of last years growth
27 + 28 Mass meeting of the Anti slavery society at Fathers Barn. Rev. W.__. Allan ___ Chapman and Bobbett speakers had a good time.
28 Brother K.E. Burhans died at 2 oclock and his son Edward at 10 in the evening of the scarlet fever
29th both buried in our grove. What a mournful spectacle to witness
2d Aug [Sep?] began cutting up corn
4th Sept - first frost nipt the vines a little
5th Earl(?)[Saul?] Harding buried of bilious fever. only sick 6 days -
6th cut buckwheat - gathered apples
14th school meeting at Morton. appointed W.W. Campbell treasurer; finished digging potatoes; cold weather hail and snow and rain fell - appearance of winter
25th Oct ground white with snow - Comfort Smith and wife here visiting
1 Nov. upwards of 2 in snow this morning sent $2.00 for the Tribune $3.00 for the Western Citizen
6 gathering corn - snow storm winter weather
7 two coloured men from St. Louis on the way to Canada came here - at night started this am - received a letter from Eliza Farnham
10 Nov. rainy day warm muddy. Father Waters visited here
11th went to Fremont trading
12th ground white with snow cold again
17th warm foggy finished picking corn
18th rain storm last night it lightninged in the west visited H.B. Waters
21 taken sick with a severe cold. handsome weather
23 rain storm - warm - my cold some better
26 rain & snow storm
28 killed hogs
29 took a load to Fremont
1 Dec. 7-1/2 above Zero clear and handsome went to Fremont load of pork visited Father Waters
4 wind stiff into N.N.W turned very cold making clover machine 5th

9th my birth day. pleasant weather I am making a clover machine
10th warm day at night rained. Dr. Stackwell and wife staid here 
11 Mr. Matthews & wife visited me at night Charles Waters and wife visited me
15th It rained all night. it began with snow
18 rainy day
17 extremely muddy
18 still cloudy and muddy
23 Dec. went to Peoria - put millers notes into Powell(?) and Brigants(?) hands for collection - warm and very muddy
25 christmas day cloudy damp day E. wind I was taken sick last night. mother sick
31 Dec. went to meeting. Text. "The Time is short" cloudy some rain very muddy
Jan. 1, 1844
cold N.E. rain storm great wolf hunt - numbers turned out notwithstanding the heavy rain 
2 snow storm turned cold after a long warm muddy disagreeable time 3 or 4 in. now
6th snow storm - wolf hunt again - cloudy nearly the whole time for 3-4 weeks
8th 8 degrees below zero - yesterday and today clear - thrashed wheat
12 warm snow going rainy
15 warm rainly and very muddy got the clover machine ready for running
23d commenced getting out clover seed
24 cold 3-1/2 day running the chaff through the machine
28 4 degrees below zero high wind clear and very cold - coldest this winter. H. Burhans visiting here
1 Feb. sleet - Father Waters visited here
Feb. 12 finished getting out clover seed; went to Fremont visited Kellogg
19th tool a load of wheat to Peoria Prices for winter wheat 62-1/2 cash spring W. 50-1/2 cash 
20th another load
21st last load - very muddy warm - geese and duck flying steam boats been up and down - some in in the lake yet
29th Feb. went to Peoria with veal shanks butter etc. very warm and muddy
1st Mar warm and showery
3d snow storm
4 clear - snow all gone - cool

1844
7th Began ploughing
9th began sowing spring wheat. grass started
15th finished ploughing for wheat. it snowed hard all day long
16th clear and warm - at night cloudy and rain and snow
17th snowing fast and cold visited Father Waters. cold N.W. wind
18th 4 degrees above zero - in snowed 2 in last night cold winters day. The Erysipelas or black tongue grows worse in Pekin - hardly a day without hearing of more or less death - truly the judgments of God are abound in the land
22nd finished thrashing for this year cold snow squally day
23d clear froze hard lat night
24 south wind warm
25th quite warm began plowing again sowed oats
26th mosquitoes in abundance rainy day
27 showery
29th cold heavy NE wind hail + rain - changed to snow and Oh! such a snow storm I never saw in the country - good sleighing all over my house - large drifts along the fences
30 clear and pleasant
Apr. 1 Father and I went to the saw mill
2nd warm south wind snow left us to day
11th ploughed my garden planted potatoes in garden
17th Apr began ploughing corn - turned cold N.E. wind 
18th ice and frost fear the forest is killed
19th frost 
21st rain gladly received
22 rain most of the day
25th heavy thunder showers all day and night - streams extremely high - hurricane 2 barns blown down - yesterday went to Peoria purchased silver spoons etx. 
26th misty rainy
28th frost - 2 degrees below freezing - clear and pleasant
1st May - showers at night thunder shower. Ab. at Washington.
5th heavy rain storm Mr. Evans child buried here
7th heavy rain storm again - thrashed H. Campbells wheat

9th May 1844. Bought 50 lb sugar. 7-1/2 cts sowed flax seed for the seed 
10th planted castor beans
13th rain
14th senatorial convention I attended at crow creek. J.T Morse nominated for the senat
15th returned. heavy rain all the way home. Mr. Field very sick
16th rainy day - rain nearly all the time - corn [rotted?] in the ground
17th rainy
18th clear - frost - 
19th Sunday rainy
20th cloudy and wet 
21 clear-cool 
froze ice and heavy frost killed our corn and beans cucumbers - 4 degrees below freezing ground frozen
22nd firing at Peoria clear and pleasant prospect of a little dry weather
23-4th replanted corn - frost killed our corn down to the ground 
25th heavy thunder showers several of our neighbors have not planted yet gloomy prospect for corn
27- 28 - 29 rain rain mud mud taking down the waggon house state Anti slavery convention in Jacksonville
1st June - Thunder and a little rain last night - a good many not done planting corn yet - for the wet weather
2 rain again
3d raised our stable and corn crib
4th finished replanting corn
5th warm and sultry - Abolition meeting at Sand Prairie. Samuel Woodrow & myself nominated for the Legislature at night onslaught lightning and thunder heavy showers in succession
6th heavy showers through the day and night
7th cloudy and wet - ground full of wet gloomy appearances for corn. over run with weeds - seven(?) not finished planting last evening in south end of the prairie the hail done much damage glass etc. several horses killed by lightning - 
9th heavy thunder storm again last night cloudy and misty
12th herd corn - began to rain toward night rained all night
13th rainy day
14th another rainy day. the Branch's higher than were known - we hear of damage done south by high water -
156th showery  bought a waggon and harness - Rec'd letter Farnham.

16th Sunday - showery
18th thunder showers at night - the Illinois never higher than it was ever known - great damage done by high water on the Mackinaw - forest(?) creek etc
19th Great Whig State convention in Peoria
20th rain again. given up raising any corn this year
28 sent for the Citizen for Father Waters.  Nelson H. Crosby and Uriah Crosby and for the Liberty t__(?) for cash - and one copy for myself
27th commenced haying
29th thunder showers
30th heavy showers all day
1st July threatened rain
2 spread out our hay cocks - appearance of rain - put them up again - bad hay weather
5th showers
8th began harvesting winter wheat
9th thunder showers - Mother quite sick
14th Uncle Ichabod sick called a Doctor
15th myself and Lurius taken sick - dry weather and warm
19th last night a dreadful thunder shower night - high winds in places prostrated the grain - record farm creek swimming(?) I very sick today
23d caty did's first heard
24th thunder showers
25th heavy showers - afraid our grain will spoil - our hay damaged already = discouraging times
26th foggy misty morning - when shall we ever have good weather - turned to rain and rained all day and night
27th wind N.E. appearance of clearing up
29th Old Mrs. Messenger died - stacking hay the water at St. Louis 38 ft 7 in above low water mark higher than it was ever known
30th another very heavy thunder shower our grain and hay takes another ducking
31st another heavy thunder storm this morning and another with large hail. winter wheat growing in the shack
1st Aug. clear N.E. wind
2nd stacked our water-rotted hay
3d thunder shower again as usual
8th Am(?) 1/2
11th Father Waters taken sick
13th went to Fremont returned by Father Waters ___ Ann a dull pain in his stomach and bowels took a heavy dose of oil and it was removed felt encouraged about him
15th Mother W. taken sick also
18th Sunday we visit Father had slight chills Friday and Saturday

had Dr. Sit___ for counsel think if we can keep off the chills he will recover at 4 oclock a severe shake of ague 1/2 an hour long - after he sweat in the night he sunk into a stupid state
19th wend down found both very sick. at about 7 oclock Father sunk into a stupid state with difficulty of breathing through the night
20th continued failing all day until 20 minutes before 5 oclock his spirit took it flight to another and better world - Mother continues quite sick
21st Father funeral held at 2 oclock. Rev. Messrs. Andrews and Gore officiated called Dr. Shaw for counsel for mother think she is going the way of Father very hot and thunder showery weather these days
27-28 quite cool.
1st Sept. sunday sacrament day - watched with Mother Waters last night - been sick 16 days. still considered dangerous. Rev. Salmon Hurlbut died to day
2nd worked on the roads Old Mr. Mitchell supposed to be dying
3rd Ref. Joseph Mitchell died aged 76 years. commenced preaching upwards of 40 years since in Vermont on a circuit with the celebrated Tommy(?) Dow
Mother quite low yet
4th went to Fremont
5th Sept five years to day since I married - Dr. Thrayer and wife visited Fathers - thrashing flax
11th taken with the fever very sick
14th better
15th very warm - Mother Waters been sick 33 days to day no better - failing - myself able to walk about some
17th warm weather Began cutting up corn - quite sick myself. last Sunday the engineer of a steam boat shot by ___ of Mr. Pasorts(?) waitors
18th I am much better today - Father went to Peoria today with butter - Mother Waters still failing
22nd sunday - first frost - Mary sick - Erysiplas [Erysipelas?] providing yet. My health better

1-11111111
1111111
Oct. 1 Mother and Ann went to Mother Water
2nd Sunday Mrs. Gore the ministers wife died of congestion fever
5 went to Fremont paid Kellogg 30.00 dollars
6th Dr. Stockwell came to see Uncle Ichabod has the bilious fever. Emerson and all of his children sick with the chills. H.B. Waters &  wife & child sick with chills and fits.
10th Mother Waters died after a protracted illness of just 8 weeks  Uncle Ichabod lays dangerously sick
16th the girls divided Mother Waters clothes etc. today
17th snowed and rained last night. yesterday began digging potatoes
18th rain - turned to snow it fell 2 in deep - winter appearance - 
19 went to Peoria cold wind
20th three negroes came from St. Louis. wind turned south warmer snow not all gone yet
21st ___ Daws dies
22nd finished digging potatoes warm again
23 ___ Daws buried here to day - warm with thunder + light showers
24the H. Clark had 200 bu wheat burned up - very high winds
27th sunday clear and pleasant Uncle Ichabod still very low - I have a severe cold. Ann also - Wm. Anderson died 24 inst.
30th Oct - helped Charles Waters build chimeny
1st Nov. Took my roof off my house and put on a new one - warm and peasant - another negro bound for Canada
2nd finished __ghing my roof
Nov. 4 Election day voted for J.G. Birney - beautiful day went to Fremont
6th Administrators sale of property of Father Waters. I bought stove 2 chairs 1 axe 2 log chains 3 candle sticks 1 bedstead sale leather-books 2 augers 1 map of Illinois - lot of brick & shingles etc. set up all night regulating the papers
7th Beautiful weather
11th moved Sarah J. Waters to my house
12th rainy + snowy
13th clear and pleasant - finished my roof abolition meeting at Peoria Walter & Darius went
22nd thrashed wheat cold and windy
23rd 6 degrees Above Zero pretty fair beginning for winter - clear
26th killed hogs - sold a stove to Jas. Holloway
28th sleet - ground covered with ice - got the horses shod - sold E. Ericsson 8 lb butter 1.00
30th Mr. & Mrs. Childs visited here at night it commenced storming
1st Dec. pleasant warm Mr. Gore preached on the state of the Nation
3d went to Peoria - left a horse hide to be tanned at Oakly's

[missing pages?]
30th Apr rain again very wet weather about these days
1st May cool. finished siding up my shop. Father and Darius went to Peoria with wheat got 50 cts a bushel good wheat brings 62-1/2 ct.
2nd May Began planting corn - a little frost this morning
5th heavy frost 4 degrees below freezing
7th another frost ice as thick as a dollar
9th finished planting corn
10th planted potatoes - dry and warm weather
13th Fauskitt got 9 bu. wheat - planted bean in the field thunder showers heavy hail shower passed along farm creek - stones as big as butternuts
16th frost and ice this morning
17th another frost
22nd great want of rain - corn not all up for want of rain - last monday Lurius taken sick with pleurisy - is very sick yet. Mary continues very low yet
25th killing frost, beans corn and even hickory leaves blackened - ice as thick as window glass - 2 degrees below freezing.
26th another frost - report says that up north wheat and corn killed by frost - very dry
29th helped Mr. White survey his timber
30th another heavy frost
1st June 1845 Father and Mother WAters funeral sermon preached by Ref. Mr. Andrews in Fremont - shower of rain. Wheat will entirely fail without rain soon
2nd laying my cellar wall - showery all day - prospects a little better
7th Mary Ann first tooth
10th very warm growing time
16th frost this morning - plenty of rain
20th worked on the road - rain
21st rainy day
1st July hard corn very growing time rain a plenty
4th July hard corn all day
7th began haying
10th very hot weather 96 degrees Mr. Brodius Thermometer 101 degrees - fine shower
16th began harvesting wheat - the Charity(?) Bugs injured it considerably.

1845
very dry - and warm
21st 104 degrees in the shade warmest weather this year - stock water getting scarce
23rd began harvesting oats - paid Elysh Browne $5.00 for share toward repairing the meeting house
25th fine shower last night
26th finished harvesting wheat and oats
Aug. 1st 1845 finished haying cutting began to draw in wheat
2nd went to Fremont Groveland and Pekin on business very dry springs and wells going dry
7th fine shower
9th Bough[t] 80 acres of land.  Attended an AntiSlavery meeting at Dillen s_tttur_(?) Rev. Mr. Spencer Addressed the meeting
10th Matthew taken sick. rain last night
11th 5 C. Gentlemen on their way to Canada came here a reward of 500 dollars offered for 2 of them. Darius came home sick
12th went for the Doctor for Mother
13th Darius very sick and Mother rain last night again.
Aug. 15th called Dr. Stockwell to Darius. Mother very sick
17th camp ministry - Mother considered dangerously sick. Darius very sick - great want of rain.
18th Rev. Mr. Douglass of Fremont died
19th Mother is at the point of death. + Darius perhaps as near
20th My Dear Mother died today. just a year since Father Waters died. Mother cheerfully resigned her spirit to her Saviour.
8th Sept. Began plowing for wheat - never known so dry - wells failing, our springs all dry.  Ambrose' well nearly dry mine also & Father entirely
21st Sept. first frost
22nd heavy frost never known so dry. Walter sick & Darius
24th another heavy frost - dry dry
29th fine rain - very sickly throughout state
1st Oct. finished sowing wheat
5th fine rain again
6th heavy frost - ice
6th Began digging potatoes
7th rain storm
8th very muddy + warm
22nd Emersons wife sick. Darius has the ague - great want of rain. Cutter + Harris suffering for want of water - wells all failing - what shall we do ...
1st Nov. Anti Slavery meeting a Morton school house Lecture by Rev. Mr. Spencer dry dry
2nd com___ season - Rev. Mr. Glisen

14th gathering corn - still continues dry the new wells drying up - warm weather  Alexander Campbell is to preach in Fremont to night - Rec'd yesterday my Almanack from N.Y.
15th Nov. sold my beef at Peoria 2-1.2 cts Butter 12-1/2.
16th vey warm - no rain yet
17th splendid rain
23rd Nov. last night the wind shifted N.W. turned very cold 10 degrees Above Zero - great want of water - Began foddering cattle
24th first snow - ground white
26th fine snow storm 4 in deep
27th 0 degrees Zero good sledding Thanksgiving to day
28th 16 degrees below zero
30th 18 degrees below zero - my dear went to church heard a Bicent___(?)   discussion - the setting at Westminster
1st Dec. 20 degrees below Zero fine beginning for winter - killed a hot went to Peoria with it got $4.00 pr ___
5th got 3 broths(?) for Waters etc. paid 1.44 etc. the morning 10 degrees below Zero
7th snow storm 6 in deep
10th 14 degrees below zero began cutting out rail timber
18th turned severely cold snowed and blew furiously 
19th 14 degrees below zero - some say 18 degrees
19th Mary Ann's Birth day - lost a cow work 10.00
20th 16 degrees below zero. Attended a funeral of a pair of twins of Charles Waters
23rd got the horses shod - settled with Dohnquist
25th Christmas - clear and cold 2 degrees below zero - drew out 3 loads nail cuts visited with Mr. Field at Darius
29th went to Pekin and engaged our Pork at  from 2-1/2 to 3-1/2 cts per lb. winter warm sleighing spoiled - corm 20 cts
wheat 60 cts oats 16 cts 
31st sold Pork for 121.35 ct.
1st Jan. 1846
A rainy day it has raised the water in the wells etc. think the mills can grind now - Hipperly mill has lain still for want of water - hope our stock water will last now - at night wind shifted into the N.W. and snowed
8th paid taxes $30.20
16th after some time warm fine weather we have another snow storm about 3 in. 3 northern travellers are bound for Canada
18th 4 degrees below Zero
19th started for Galesburg went through Farmington staid over night with Mr. Willen 6 miles beyond Farmington.

20th a heavy snow storm - all day - 6 in. made in it 23 __(?) - through Knoxville A. Galesburgh - to Uncle John Waters
21st saw a perpetual motion machine
22nd returned to Harkins settlement
23 arrived at home - snow again
26th Father & Darius started for Fox river - visiting - snow nearly gone - extremely muddy
29th Rained all night and all day - Oh how muddy
1st Feb. - warm - sent to N. York for the N. Yorker
4th warm beautiful weeather with ground settled frost all out
Saturday 14th 16 ~ 18 snow storm all day - 7 or 8 in deep
19th another snow storm - all from N.E. 12 in deep yesterday 3 degrees above zero - drew wood for Ambrose
20th 21st thrashed wheat fine sleighing
22nd 11 degrees below zero
26th 8 degrees below zero - saw wood for me Rec'd a letter from Aaron W. Burhans
28th another NE snow storm 5 or 6 in
1st March - cold pleasant morning - communion at the Meeting House
3d 4 degrees above zero - thrashed wheat - last night visited Beckers
6th snow going fast - very muddy
9th began breaking up the Timothy meadow and began cutting up corn stalks grass begins to grow
9th sent a lattice(?) to C. Muller ___
11th thunder frequent showers through the day - snow drifts still remain
18th Scott came after shrubery. G. Parker taking the census. Served a pr___ on R. Scott for harboring negroes. I want security for his appearance at court - bond of 400 dollars - warm with thunder showers
20th ground white with snow
23rd Cotton M. Roberts died at Groveland - rainly all day
24th attended the funeral. rainy to day
26th ground white with snow
27th went to Peoria
30th Mar. began sowing wheat
1st Apr. cold N.E. wind
6th heavy rain storm from the S. ponds all full once more

1846
10th yesterday received the princess(?) plate the attach of the Lion - today a rain storm again
12th 9 degrees below freezing cold NW wind - sent yesterday $2.00 to C. Muller N.Y.
13th 12 degrees below freezing
14th school began
20th plowed my garden sowed oats and flax seed
21st attended a weeding - Minerva married to Dr. Rogers of Washington. Began plowing for corn - on old ground plum trees begin to blossom
28th rain storm. Old Mr. Willard retiring to Ohio
29th rain all night and still continues
1st May 1846 still rainy. finished Ambrose's fence began furrowing for corn
4th rain storm again.
5th Began planting corn
6th another rain storm - attended a Mass meeting of the Abolitionists at Peoria heard Mr. Codding and Mr. Blanchard lecture in the evening a mob drove them out
7th planted corn - the assessor come along - valued personal property at

            250 horses      1846
            315
            170
            450

          1185

13th got caught in a very heavy shower of rain coming from Fremont
14th rainy all day
15th began planting corn on the old meadow ground
18th finished planting corn - planted potatoes fine growing time - our peach trees nearly all died - apples trees - much injured last winter - the measuring(?) or canker worm - on our apples trees
21st put gin - for colt - planted beans - rainy and muddy
31st camp meeting at Pleasant Grove - thunder showers to day - staid at home
1st June - every able bodied man notified to appear at Fremont - to raise Volunteers for the Mexican war - war with all its horrors I fear is our doom.

2nd June - Began breaking prairie
6th June small showers very dry for a week past - rather cool weather - the chintz bugs destroy spring wheat - Mr. Codding lectured at the meeting house in the evening - all stir and bustle(?) in raising volunteers for the Mexican war
18th heavy thunder shower with a gale broke down 2 apple trees
19th Gilbert Cornwell arrived here
20th went to Peoria for his goods
24th began haying
26th began harvesting on account of the rust. showery time - wheat generally rusted through the Country. Bad news from Texas - sickness annoy(?) the soldiers - 300 men killed by the Mexicans
27th first green peas
28th first cucumbers
29th Great rain storm
4th July finished harvesting winter grain
6th helped Mr. Campbell harvest - heavy thunder showers
7th thunder showers again - yesterday purchased a patent hay rake - wheat et down to 25 c. pork 1.00
9th extreme hot weather 98 degrees
15th began harvesting spring wheat - turned quite cool - the Bugs nearly destroy all our spring wheat
20th first green corn dry harvest weather
21st finished cutting spring wheat
22nd last night thunder showers all night
24th Ambrose and Watts taken sick
25th Sarah take sick - stormy times - very sickly in Peoria
27th began harvesting oats - Darius & myself - thunder showers - very warm
8th very warm weather all this week - showery for several days - Lightning struck the meeting house - short turn ago - lightning struck Mr. Scotts Barn and burned it. 
Marbury house and stable also - struck by lightning
21st Father took sick - worked on the road
22nd got a doctor for Father - 
25th G. Cornwell moved onto his farm Father some better
26th showery all day 
27th ___

Aug. 28, 1846 - Walter's wife (Mary) died after a long sickness - Mr. Platt died today - quite subtly (suddenly? sultry?) - still showerey
1st Sept. very hot weather - 90 degrees - pulled onions
4th thrashing seed wheat - heavy rain - 
5th and 6th rain
7th cleared up we hope - began sowing wheat - very sickly through the country
11th hot weather - Owen (Oven?) gave out to day - so very warm and sultry - yesterday Mr. Saml Mosbry buried - very sickly all over the state.
12th Mrs. Samual Harris buried. Began cutting up corn
14th Mr. Hungerford(?) buried - a little cooler weather
21st Sept. Darius P. Roberts has a daughter born.  Mr. Field get 36 bu wheat of us for seed - pleasant weather
24th last thunder showers all night
25th rained all night and still raining - Ambrose family threatened with ague again Cornwell's family also
Sunday the 27th Ambrose has a chill also Lanyra Danial Julia and Rimze(?) - surely a sick house
28th Mr. Cornwell died
29th went to Peoria for medicine for Ambros
3rd Oct. sickness increases  - Bradshaw, Edina, N. Brown soon in my family
13th Oct. first frost - rain in the afternoon Ambrose has the ague again for the 3d time
15th sent letter to N.Y for pictures etc.
16th heavy rain with thunder - about half done digging potatoes - the rot in them
17th first snow
18th 12 degrees below freezing
19th another frozen(?) - cold - Mr. Sharps boy got killed by a pit deer of Mr. White when going to school
23rd Ambrose took the ague the 4th time all his family down again - drew sand for planting
30th polished my bedrooms - finished digging potatoes - after 3 weeks
Nov. 1 1846 cold NE wind and cloudy for several days - went to Morton(?) school house to meeting. Mr. Gore just returned with his new wife
10th began harvesting corn. Ambrose and family still sick with the Ague - warm weather about these days
12th Mrs. C. Pottre (Potter?) visiting here
13th rainy day - turned cool
17th got 2 loads corn
18th 2 loads
19th 2 loads run - snow squalls - cold - wet - settled with Dahlquist - 450 due us - sold our last yoke oxen for 30.00 dollars. Ambrose still sick.

1847
26th turned cold snow 1 in deep cold NE wind
27th a winters morning
1st Dec. Rainy day - worked about the house
7th rainy - turned cold and sleet
9th Birth day - clear and pleasant - very rough roads - got horses shod
15th finished picking corn - handsome weather
16th snow storm fine sleighing - got my horses shod
21st killed hogs get $1,622
25 christmas warm
27th warm - flies in the house - frost nearly out
29th rainy day
31st rained - last night misty - horrid muddy - rainy day
1st Jan. 1847 - rainy - turned to hail - Ann Sick 10 oclock and 12 min after ___ night Ellen Maria was born - weighing 9 lbs
4th went to Fremont snow storm settled with Mr. Wright - paid taxes of $37.90
6th snowed all day
7th cold 12 degrees below zero to cold to work
8th 13 degrees below zero wind south grows warmer
9th 8 degrees below zero - went to Peoria with oats
10th 19 degrees below zero - clear day
11th 8 degrees below
9th last night at bed time 16 degrees below zero
12th thrashed oats - wind south
14th warm snow going off
16th cold again 8 degrees below zero
22nd finished thrashing oats - last night at bed time 14 degrees below zero wouth wind - very chilly - George Water got home
25th finished taking off oats 
26th thrashed corn for market - 16 cts per bushel
27th 4 degrees below zero - pleasant weather
29th snow storm 4 inches
30th went to Peoria got a new thrashing machine sold my mare
3rd 6 degrees below zero
4th 7 degrees below zero thrashed wheat paid 3.00 for a cuttwaler(?) to Dahlquist
6th got some machinery for the thrashing machine at Peoria - crossed on the ice
9th evening had a Library meeting - Elected 7 trustees - Mr. Hurlburt died yesterday
12th - Brundint(?) sent a letter to Vermont - for a  Constitution(?)
15th John Brodin buried - very sickly in Pekin - Willards child just alive E.G. Emerson appointed to rent the farm and offer it for sale
20th heavy rain - muddy time
21st very muddy and squally
26th snow storm
27th went to Burketts sawmill cold snow squally day
1st Mar. drove wood for Ambrose on a sled - cold N.W. wind
11th adopted Constitution and Bylaws of Mosta(?) Library - cold weather

13th started our new thrashing machine
19th sunday still cold N. wind
15th tight winter weather
17th went to Birketts saw mill paid him $49.60 for lumber - warm today - after a long cold spell
24th Rec'd another book for the library
27th finished thrashing wheat pleasant weather cold mornings
10th finished hauling of wheat (winter at 55 ct 233 bushels
13th Apr. began plowing for wheat
18th cold - froze the run solid - cold for several weeks - think only 14 degrees above zero
19th began sowing wheat - quite warm to day
22nd thunder showers - after a long dry time - grass now will grow I hope
24th Anti slavery meeting at Pleasant Grove - a lecture by Mr. Cady of Barrington (or Farmington?) - sowed flax to day
27th Father sick got Dr. Bous. to see him. Co. Com Abel Kings___ drowned in the Mackinaw River - Charles Warner died very suddenly of congestive fever.
29th Apr. plowed my garden
30th sick myself
30th began ploughing for corn
1st May cool wet weather 
7th Jane(?) Emerson died
8th attended the funeral -___ cold North West wind
12th Rained all last night and to day
13th finished sacking corn - commenced laying off for corn - sold a prairie plow to Frank Gay jr. for 17 dollars payable middle of July
15th began planting corn
16th Mary very sick
20th May hauling corn to Westly City  planting corn in my orchard - The assessor come here

22nd finished hauling off corn  Father had Dr. Harris to day
24th went to Peoria - rained all the afternoon of course got wet
26th Frost this morning cold and wet for several weeks past - corn rotted in the ground - finished planing corn
29th took potatoes and oats to Peoria prices oats 25 c potatoes .40 corn .30 wheat .85 - engaged a prairie plow for 15.00 - 
30th rainy
31st May - got my lumber measured out - paid $18.19 
June 5 hauling lumber for my Barn - cold N.E. wind -poor prospects for corn - people still planting and re-planting what winter killed throughout the western states - wheat 1.00 corn .30 oats .25 potatoes .40
12th drawing shingle timber - heavy hail storm caught out in it - hail stones as large round as hen's eggs - $2000 damage in Peoria
19th Began snowing blue grass corn very late
15th Uncle Wilson Phelps around here on a visit from N.Y.  state near Rochester Paid for the Citizen to No. 50 Volume 6
22nd hot weather Walter started up to Alvord yesterday - last night a frightful thunder storm from the N.E. the hail and wind done much damage up towards Washington
4th July sacrament administered - had Ellen Maria christened
11th first cucumber
12th began harvesting fall wheat - hot and dry - 94 degrees and no wind at all
17th showers around us - very hot - 100 degrees a fine shower which we stood in great need of
18th Elizabeth Mosbry died this morning aged about 18
20th the daughter of Mr. Hancock died this morning
21st cut out flax - heavy thunder storm with some hail
24th heavy rain storm 
25th thunder showers pray (or fear?) our wheat will grow in this dozen(?)
26th cold N.E. wind 
27th almost cold enough for a frost - wheat spring almost good for nothing for rust - Seth(?) Luvis buried to day.

1847
30th July only 8 degrees above freezing - Began drawing in wheat
10th Aug. Darius taken sick with a chill
12th called a Dr. Harry to  Darius - went to Peoria got a barrel of Hydraulick cement - showery about these days
18th Aug. finished drawing in oats.
20 W. Campbell's house raised - Darius getting better
19th began sowing wheat
24th Harvey Campbell's youngest child buried here - Darius begins to work again
30th Thrashing wheat for seed - Mr. Emerson taken sick with the fever
1st Sept. Began sowing wheat on the sod. went to Fremont. Darius & Walter went to Peoria
3d Sarah Castle buried to day
7th great rain storm with heavy thunder all day and night
8th rainy still
9th first frost
10th Hobs lost a child of measles or scarlet fever
11th took four persons on the under ground rail road
14th another frost - killed pumpkins vines etc.
15th Mrs. Holloway died of congestive fever
17th she was buried at our place
18th finished sowing wheat
20th Began cutting up corn - got seed wheat from J.T. Ayers - sent to N.Y. for Pritonal(?) sheet
25th cut up corn in Ambrose' orchard - Old Mr. Loomis died.
29th Sept. Austin Harding married Caroline Cromwell (or Cornwall?)
30th went to mill with 20 bu. wheat - Father had a chill yesterday
1st Oct. warm day Began breaking up the meadow thrashed peas - Father very sick - 
3d Sunday heavy hail storm last night - warm today - 
4th Began gathering Apples
7th went to the Congregational associat(?) hear Mr. Wright preach
13th first killing frost ice etc.

14th Oct. 1847 - a hard freeze this time - gathering Fathers apples
18th Began digging potatoes
20th Joel Clark married to Sarah S. Waters
21st rained all last night and all day to day
22nd drew in the onions
23rd went to Fremont purchased a stove for 19.00 dollars paper 2.25
24th rainy day - Ann taken sick yesterday - fever constantly - Comfort Smith's boys visiting here
27th digging potatoes - cold frozen ground - potatoes frozen the morning 11 degrees above zero
28th Mr. Crandall's house burnt down this morning
30th working for W.W. Campbell lathing
31st Sunday rainy day warm weather
4th Nov. working on Mr. Crandall's house
6th rainy day
10th Paid taxes $39.72 - Melvin died
11th raised Mr. Crandall's house - cold chilly day - killed 2 bees(beefs?)
13th rainy day - a little hail & snow
17th Cnancy Crandall died this morning of Typhus fever - began harvesting corn in the big field - warm weather
18th Betsy Hancock died of Typhus fever - sold the old farm of Luther Waters ___ for $1550.00
19th worked on the Hepperly hill.
21st heavy rain storm
23rd rainy day
24th snowy day
25th thanksgiving snow all day
26th clear day - killed a beef(?)
1st Done gathering corn
2nd snow storm
8th bought 20 sheep of Mr. Kirk for 15 dollars rained last night and a heavy wind - blew down fences
7th Augustus Greely died at Groveland.
9th my Birth day had a wild Turkey Baked - rain hail and snow storm
10th went to Peoria with Beef & apples - wheat worth 75 to 80 beef 2.50 pork 2.00 
17th started for springfield to deposit $910 for 160 acres of land 
18th arrived at Springfield - went to Uncle Lymans

spent the sabbath there returned home on the 20th & 21st very cold 6 degrees below zero - found Father sick
24th went to Fremont sold port at 218  -paid .62-1/2 for Treasurers Books
25th Christmas - had a baked turkey 4 degrees below zero
26th 9 degrees below zero - clear and pleasant
Dec. 31st - very warm and horrid muddy - drew my rafters out of the gulph
1st Jan. 1848 pleasant day went to Fremont got my deed of Millers land pork declining dull at 2.00 dollars
7th took our last pork to market 7030 lbs 2.18 cts - 25 hogs - last year 8074  30 hogs 1.70 cts.
9th snow squalls last night - turned cold 7 degrees below zero
13th and 14th very foggy & muddy  Father sick again. little Polly sick
Jan. 20th sold 100 acres of land - drew/drove(?) writings to day - for $360.00 - warm beautiful weather
22nd Thrashed on our winter wheat - the small pox in Mackinaw Town - the gangrene soar throat primarily in the neighborhood west of us - very ____ measles all around us
The Assessor T.R. Babcock
1848
horses         $250
cattle           235.00
hogs & sheep   45.00
waggons and carriages  105.00
money loaned       450.00
all other property     250.00
Land        15 prime   3842.00

                   $5177.00

25th warm foggy rain storm musketoes out - 2 lambs today twins
1st Feb. fine day finished Ambrose barn timber  Library meeting - chosen Trustee
4th cold high N.W. wind
5th finished hewing my barn timber - snow squalls
6th bitter cold
12th took Flaxseed to Fremont - got 5 bitts. the Jail at Fremont burnt down a few days since - warm and dry
15th rec'd of E.G.Emerson 59.17 cts. - rec'd division of rent 8.00 dollars 40 cts. yet due
Rec'd of the Estate by the administrators $158.60 - muddy very smokey rods
18th thunder storm extremely muddy - our coal Bank has been worked by mistake - been here to day
20th after several days rain it cleared away - Mary very sick Darius sick & Father sick etc etc.
27th Sunday - south wind - meeting continues in Groveland - 80 converts - it is said
2nd snowed all day 3 or 6 in deep
3d last night wind shifted N.W. turned bitter cold 3 degrees below zero
5th 6 degrees below zero - inoculated my family with the Rim(?) Pox - measles prevail
7th went to Fremont Election for adopting the new Constitution bought a barrel of sugar $7.00 per br.
8th went to Peoria to buy Books for the library - wheat 70 cts sugar $6.00 a bushel(?) - warm day
9th snow fell 2 in. last night
11th finished thrashing wheat. Darius had an ague chill
12th very high N.W. wind cool
13th cold cold again
14th finished thrashing oats etc. Darius had another shake of Ague - Nelson Aloord and wife come here on a visit - cold and windy
13th Nancy McGinnis dies of measles
17th last night T.J. Ayers oldest daughter died of measles.

hauling of wheat at 75c - framing Ambrose Barn - Darius sick again with Ague - And Father likewise
21st Began sowing spring wheat
23d finished drawing off oats 187 bu. at 16 cts wheat now 85 cts. Wm. Moobry buried today
24th settled with Mr. Wright due us $4.75 - fire burnt up several thousand rods on the prairie
26th heavy rain last night flurries of snow to day
30th got Library Book - cattle nearly get all the grass they want - finished laying of Ambrose Barn
1st Apr. very muddy - rain every few days
3d rain storm again
4th still raining. James T. Ayers wife buried to day - made soap(?) troughs Mr. Birkey died last week Wednesday
10th Mrs. Oliver (Cornelius daughter) died today - sent tellers (letters?) to N. York and Chicago on the 8th for 8 copies of the Mammoth Pictora et.
18th Walter married the second time to Fanny Howring(?) - very cold and windy - 
19th 8 degrees below freezing - peach trees in bloom. Job Hodges wife and Frank's oldest son died with the measles
22nd finished laying of my Barn and drawing off potatoes at 15c. 158 bu - $23.70.
24th heavy frost and freeze - 6 degrees below freezing. peaches and plums all killed I think - Edwin sick
26th Walter taken sick
Sunday 29th Darius taken sick with scarlet fever - ___ throat nearly all of us sick - dark times!
30th froze ice in the bucket this morning - most all of us sick
1st May Ploughed my garden the sick getting some better
3d ____ (Kiked?) horse
5th hail storm
6th began planting corn
12th heavy frost 2 degrees below freezing
13th finished plowing my orchard
16th fine rain - which was much needed.

1848 
How to test the weight of gold coins by a comparison with silver
Half Eagles is equal in weight to      .31-1/2 cts of silver
Sovereign    ditto                              .30             ditto
Napoleon is a shade lighter than       .25             ditto
X Thaler(?)     ditto                            .50             ditto
10 Gilder is equal in weight to           .25              ditto
Doubloon      ditto                             1.00            ditto
The test is with American silver except in the case of the half Eable when you use two dimes and a fair spanish shilling
Cure of Whoping Cough
1/2 pt sweet Olive Oil same quantity of conversion(?) hiks(?) cut fine simmer moderately 2 or 3 hours add honey to make it palatable  1/2 tablespoon for adult if taken 4 or 5 times - will remove it in a few days
Cure for a Burn
scoop inside of a potato mix sweet oil and turpentine make a poultice apply immediately
17th Began planting corn in my orchard - Birth day supper at Walters
23rd finished planting corn - frequent showers all day - Polly sick
25 planted potatoes
26th went to Peoria - Richard Higgins wife died - Crosby lost a child
28th little Polly not expected to live
June 6th raised Ambrose' and my Barn - frost this morning great prospect of wheat & corn
12th Aunt Eunice and Tyler arrived here from N. York
14th began working on the roads
22nd went to Westly City - raining
23 - tremendous thunder storms
24th - Anti Slavery meeting at Pleas. Grove - the rust took our wheat again - Mr. Samuel Holter died a few days ago
28th Began harvesting wheat
1st July - done a long days work harvesting - David T. Sill fell from a building - yesterday - 20 ft taken up for dead. Sarah has a son.
4th July first cucumbers & potatoes.

Scrofular Tumors w___(?) etc.
yolk of eggs beat up add as much pa__(?) salt as will dissolve - apply every 12 hours
Bronchocele(?)
mix the ashes of burnt sponge with lard equal parts - rub on 3 or 4 times a day
also the juice of milk weed
Alkaline poultice
take lye rather weak warm it stir in slippery elm bark sufficient to form a poultice good for inflammation of the breast white swellings scrofula etc.
Yellow Salve
wild indigo boil down add butter bees wax + mutton tallow
good for all kinds of scrofulas
Green salve
turpentine 1/2 lb bayberry tallow 1/2 do mix + add - sweet oil if necessary
for scrofula ulcers
Saline wash
fine salt 1 oz spirits 1/2 pt - vinegar 1/2 pt - rain water 1/2 pt - exutted(?) cooling work for inflammation of the brain etc.
After pains
pepper + spirits simmer together - flannels dipped in it  apply to the belly - give hop tea in milk to drink press on the belly
Puerperal fever
1st emitic 2nd antimony to cause perspiration 3rd mustard to the bowels
flooding or Lochia
apply vinegar spirits + water to the lower parts of the bowels - give astringents - as cold tea of fleabane or beth root - salt + water is very good
Weather Proof Cement
TAke of fine sand one part, clay two parts; mix with linseed oil or cotton seed or palm oil, to the consistency required and put on with a trowel or stiff brush - it is equal in durability to marble.

Mandrake pills
extract of mandrake  2 parts
capsicum   1 ditto
mix. form into Pills common size - done 3-4 every night sufficient to regulate the bowels for liver, bilious, dispreal(?), dyspeptic or nervous complaints
Bronchitis Asthma Pills
make a pill of tan loaf sugar and skunk cabbage root - take 1 every 1, 2 or 3 hours as it agrees with the stomach - untill cured
Fever & ague powder
sulphate of quinine  - 1 sample
capsicum                  2   ditto
mix and rub well in a mortar divide into 10 powders give 1 every 2 hours in syrup after having cleansed the stomach and bowels
Disphoritic Powds
green opium - 1 drall(?)
Camphor        2  ditto
Pulverized spices    1 ditto
cream of tartar or super carbonate of soda 1 oz.
Pulverize separately this mix - tn gv as 1/2 tea spoonfull as often as necessary
Blood root for Scarlet Fever
a tea spoon full in 1/2 pt of boiling water strain off the infusion sweeten with honey dose a tea spoon full for a child from 2 to 4 yrs repeat every hour through the day if the child can bear it - if the surface gets ulcerated wash the surface with the same
Anti Emitic drops
salt 2 oz
capsicum 1 oz
vinegar 1 qt
Does - table spoon full whenever a great nausea
Grarl
root of Jacobs ladder - 2 oz - make a decoction for common drink
fomentations
hops tansy wormwood hoarhound catnip handful of each - boiling with vinegar + water
stimulatory fomentations
Red pepper 2 oz bruised mustard seed 2 oz alcohol or spirits 2 qts - simmer(?) a few minutes

spices    2 ditto

mix well together dose 1/2 as much as will stay on 5 cts price every 4 hours mixed with honey

Certain cure for Ague
10 hours before the chill take 1/2 table spoon of sulphur + the same of Cream of Tartar put in whiskey sufficient to mix it. keep warm until after the time for the chill. repeat if necessary
To Preserve Boots + Shoes
2 parts of Tallow 1 of Rosin melted together applied warm not hot to burn the leather apply on the soles and uppers untill the bottom(?) if(is?) full  
to polish take the following dissolve 1 oz of Bees wax in 1 oz. of spirits of Turpentine - add a tea spoon full of Lamp black after the tallow is thoroughly dried in apply the blacking - do not dry it by the fire

Salamatus         ditto                equal parts

Saline wash
Cooling wash
fine salt - spirits - vinegar. Rain water equal parts - for inflammation of the brain etc.
Syrup for Dysentery
Rhubarb and wild cherry bark, a hand full 4 table spoonsfull of sugar simmer a while. Dose give a tablespoonfull every 15 minutes make it fresh every day - and add a little Brandy
Blackberry syrup

Varnish for pictures
Take Isinglass or gum arabic and dilute it in water - and with a large camel hair brush spread it over the drawing after it is dry take gum mastic diluted in alcohol and give it another coat
To make oil drying
Put it in a bottle over a fire that will keep it in a slight abulition - linseed or nut oil to each pound add 3 oz. litharge reduced to a fine powder
Economical white house paint
skim milk 2 qts fresh slacked lime 8 oz. linseed oil 6 oz. white burgandy pitch 2 oz. spanish white 3 pounds the lime to be Slacked in water exposed to the air mixed in about 1/4 of the milk the oil in which the pitch is previously dissolved to be added a little at a time then the rest of the milk in afterward the spanish white this quantity is sufficient for 27 square yard two coats - the expense is only 10 pence
Varnish for coloured drawings
Take of Canada balsam 1 oz. spirits of Turpentine 2 oz. mix them together before this composition is applied the drawing should be sized with a solution of Isinglass in water and when dry apply the varnish with a camels' hair ____
To destroy superfluous Hair
fresh lime stone 1 oz. pure potass. 1 drachu, sulphuret of Potass 1 drachu if the hair be first washed or soaked in warm water (130 degrees Fahr.) for 10 minutes the article formed into a thin paste with warm water and applied when warm will so effectually destroy the hair in 5 or 6 minutes that it may be removed by working the skin with flannel it is a powerful caustic and should be removed as soon as it begins to inflame the skin by washing it of white vinegar - it softens the skin and greatly improves the appearance.
